Name: Keychain
Description: Adversaries may acquire credentials from Keychain. Keychain (or Keychain Services) is the macOS credential management system that stores account names, passwords, private keys, certificates, sensitive application data, payment data, and secure notes. There are three types of Keychains: Login Keychain, System Keychain, and Local Items (iCloud) Keychain. The default Keychain is the Login Keychain, which stores user passwords and information. The System Keychain stores items accessed by the operating system, such as items shared among users on a host. The Local Items (iCloud) Keychain is used for items synced with Apple’s iCloud service.

Name: Securityd Memory
Description: An adversary may obtain root access (allowing them to read securityd’s memory), then they can scan through memory to find the correct sequence of keys in relatively few tries to decrypt the user’s logon keychain. This provides the adversary with all the plaintext passwords for users, WiFi, mail, browsers, certificates, secure notes, etc.

Name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Description: Adversaries may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the target browser. Web browsers commonly save credentials such as website usernames and passwords so that they do not need to be entered manually in the future. Web browsers typically store the credentials in an encrypted format within a credential store; however, methods exist to extract plaintext credentials from web browsers.

Name: Windows Credential Manager
Description: Adversaries may acquire credentials from the Windows Credential Manager. The Credential Manager stores credentials for signing into websites, applications, and/or devices that request authentication through NTLM or Kerberos in Credential Lockers (previously known as Windows Vaults).

Name: Password Managers
Description: Adversaries may acquire user credentials from third-party password managers. Password managers are applications designed to store user credentials, normally in an encrypted database. Credentials are typically accessible after a user provides a master password that unlocks the database. After the database is unlocked, these credentials may be copied to memory. These databases can be stored as files on disk.

Name: Data Destruction
Description: Adversaries may destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources. Data destruction is likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files or data on local and remote drives. Common operating system file deletion commands such as del and rm often only remove pointers to files without wiping the contents of the files themselves, making the files recoverable by proper forensic methodology. This behavior is distinct from Disk Content Wipe and Disk Structure Wipe because individual files are destroyed rather than sections of a storage disk or the disk's logical structure.

Name: Data Destruction
Description: The malware has destroyed Linux-based databases as part of its ransomware capabilities.

Name: Data Destruction
Description: The malware can corrupt files by overwriting the first 1 MB with `0xcc` and appending random extensions.

Name: Data Encoding
Description: Adversaries may encode data to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system. Use of data encoding may adhere to existing protocol specifications and includes use of ASCII, Unicode, Base64, MIME, or other binary-to-text and character encoding systems. Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.

Name: Standard Encoding
Description: Adversaries may encode data with a standard data encoding system to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system that adheres to existing protocol specifications. Common data encoding schemes include ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME. Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.

Name: Non-Standard Encoding
Description: Adversaries may encode data with a non-standard data encoding system to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a non-standard data encoding system that diverges from existing protocol specifications. Non-standard data encoding schemes may be based on or related to standard data encoding schemes, such as a modified Base64 encoding for the message body of an HTTP request.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: Adversaries may encrypt data on target systems or on large numbers of systems in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. They can attempt to render stored data inaccessible by encrypting files or data on local and remote drives and withholding access to a decryption key. This may be done in order to extract monetary compensation from a victim in exchange for decryption or a decryption key (ransomware) or to render data permanently inaccessible in cases where the key is not saved or transmitted.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has maliciously encrypted victim's database systems and demanded a cryptocurrency ransom be paid.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description:
The malware performs AES-CBC encryption on files under ~/Documents, ~/Downloads, and
~/Desktopwith a fixed key and renames files to give them a .encextension. Only files with sizes 
less than 500MB are encrypted.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt data and leave a ransom note.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware encrypts user files and demands that a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware encrypts a set of file extensions on a host, deletes the original files, and provides a ransom note with no contact information.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware encrypts the victims machine followed by asking the victim to pay a ransom.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt files on a targeted system, appending them with the suffix .seth.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware encrypts victim files using RSA-2048 encryption and demands a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has used a combination of symmetric (AES) and asymmetric (RSA) encryption to encrypt files. Files have been encrypted with their own AES key and given a file extension of .RYK. Encrypted directories have had a ransom note of RyukReadMe.txt written to the directory.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware uses a multi-threaded encryption process that can partially encrypt targeted files with the OpenSSL library and the AES256 algorithm.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware will search for an RSA encryption key and then perform its encryption process on the system files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware encrypts files on the local machine and mapped drives prior to displaying a note demanding a ransom.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt files on victim systems and demands a ransom to decrypt the files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has used RSA and AES-CBC encryption algorithm to encrypt a list of targeted file extensions.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt files on a compromised host with RC6, and encrypts the key with RSA-1024.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has leveraged the CryptoPP C++ library to encrypt files on target systems using AES and appended filenames with `.enc`.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt data on victim's machines using RSA and AES algorithms in order to extort a ransom payment for decryption.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware encrypts user files and disk structures like the MBR with 2048-bit RSA.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt files on infected machines to extort victims.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has used the open-source library, Mbed Crypto, and generated AES keys to carry out the file encryption process.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has disrupted systems by encrypting files on targeted machines, claiming to decrypt files if a ransom payment is made. the malware has used the ChaCha algorithm, based on Salsa20, and an RSA algorithm to encrypt files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has encrypted files, including core Windows OS files, using RSA-OAEP MGF1 and then demanded Bitcoin be paid for the decryption key.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has a ransomware component that encrypts files with an AES key that is also RSA-1028 encrypted.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has encrypted files and demanded Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can use an embedded RSA-2048 public key to encrypt victim data for ransom.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can use an embedded NTRU public key to encrypt data for ransom.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt all non-system files using a hybrid AES-RSA algorithm prior to displaying a ransom note.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware uses standard encryption library functions to encrypt files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has encrypted files using an RSA key though the `CryptEncrypt` API and has appended filenames with ".lock64".

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can use public and private key pair encryption to encrypt files for ransom payment.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has encrypted drives using the core encryption mechanism from DiskCryptor.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has the ability to encrypt system data and add the ".cuba" extension to encrypted files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can use CreateIoCompletionPort(), PostQueuedCompletionStatus(), and GetQueuedCompletionPort()to rapidly encrypt files, excluding those with the extensions of .exe, .dll, and .lnk. It has used a different AES-256 encryption key per file with a bundled RAS-4096 public encryption key that is unique for each victim. the malware can use “Windows Restart Manager” to ensure files are unlocked and open for encryption.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt files using AES, RSA, and RC4 and will add the ".clop" extension to encrypted files.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has the ability to encrypt Windows devices, Linux devices, and VMWare instances.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can encrypt files with the ChaCha20 cypher and using a multithreaded process to increase speed.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware can import a hard-coded RSA 1024-bit public key, generate a 128-bit RC4 key for each file, and encrypt the file in place, appending .lockedto the filename.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
Description: The malware has encrypted files and disks using AES-128-CBC and RSA-2048.

Name: Data Encrypted for Impact

Name: Data from Cloud Storage Object

Name: Data from Cloud Storage

Name: Data from Configuration Repository
Description: Adversaries may collect data related to managed devices from configuration repositories. Configuration repositories are used by management systems in order to configure, manage, and control data on remote systems. Configuration repositories may also facilitate remote access and administration of devices.

Name: SNMP (MIB Dump)
Description: Adversaries may target the Management Information Base (MIB) to collect and/or mine valuable information in a network managed using Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).

Name: Network Device Configuration Dump
Description: Adversaries may access network configuration files to collect sensitive data about the device and the network. The network configuration is a file containing parameters that determine the operation of the device. The device typically stores an in-memory copy of the configuration while operating, and a separate configuration on non-volatile storage to load after device reset. Adversaries can inspect the configuration files to reveal information about the target network and its layout, the network device and its software, or identifying legitimate accounts and credentials for later use.

Name: Data from Information Repositories
Description: Adversaries may leverage information repositories to mine valuable information. Information repositories are tools that allow for storage of information, typically to facilitate collaboration or information sharing between users, and can store a wide variety of data that may aid adversaries in further objectives, or direct access to the target information. Adversaries may also abuse external sharing features to share sensitive documents with recipients outside of the organization.

Name: Code Repositories

They may be hosted internally or privately on third party sites such as Github, GitLab, SourceForge, and BitBucket. Users typically interact with code repositories through a web application or command-line utilities such as git.

Description: Adversaries may search connected removable media on computers they have compromised to find files of interest. Sensitive data can be collected from any removable media (optical disk drive, USB memory, etc.) connected to the compromised system prior to Exfiltration. Interactive command shells may be in use, and common functionality within cmd may be used to gather information.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: Once a removable media device is inserted back into the first victim, the malware collects data from it that was exfiltrated from a second victim.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware has the ability to steal written CD images and files of interest from previously connected removable drives when they become available again.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware searches for files on attached removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions every five seconds.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware has a package that collects documents from any inserted USB sticks.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware can collect data from removable media and stage it for exfiltration.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware contains a module that collects documents with certain extensions from removable media or fixed drives connected via USB.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware has the ability to extract data from removable devices connected to the endpoint.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware can find, encrypt, and upload files from fixed and removable drives.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware can collect jpeg files from connected MTP devices.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware steals files based on an extension list if a USB drive is connected to the system.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware FilePakMonitor component has the ability to collect files from removable devices.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on removable media and copies them to a staging area. The default file types copied would include data copied to the drive by the malware.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware can scan all .exe files located in the USB drive.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware can monitor removable drives and exfiltrate files matching a given extension list.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware contains a module to collect data from removable drives.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware steals user files from removable media with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description:
The malware copies files with certain extensions from USB devices to
a predefined directory.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware has the ability to collect data from USB devices.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The malware can find and collect data from removable media devices.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: The threat actors RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: A the threat actors file stealer has the capability to steal data from newly connected logical volumes on a system, including USB drives.

Name: Data from Removable Media
Description: An the threat actors backdoor may collect the entire contents of an inserted USB device.

Name: Data Manipulation
Description: Adversaries may insert, delete, or manipulate data in order to influence external outcomes or hide activity, thus threatening the integrity of the data. By manipulating data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, or decision making.

Name: Stored Data Manipulation
Description: The malware created a copy of the SolarWinds Orion software source file with a .bkextension to backup the original content, wrote the malware using the same filename but with a .tmpextension, and then moved the malware using MoveFileExto the original filename with a .csextension so it could be compiled within Orion software.

Name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
Description: The malware has a function that can watch the contents of the system clipboard for valid bitcoin addresses, which it then overwrites with the attacker's address.

Name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
Description: The malware can monitor the clipboard for cryptocurrency addresses and change the intended address to one controlled by the adversary.

Name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
Description: The malware is capable of modifying email content, headers, and attachments during transit.

Name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
Description: The threat actors has used DYEPACK to manipulate SWIFT messages en route to a printer.

Name: Stored Data Manipulation
Description: The threat actors has used DYEPACK to create, delete, and alter records in databases used for SWIFT transactions.

Name: Runtime Data Manipulation
Description: The threat actors has used DYEPACK.FOX to manipulate PDF data as it is accessed to remove traces of fraudulent SWIFT transactions from the data displayed to the end user.

Name: Stored Data Manipulation
Description: Adversaries may insert, delete, or manipulate data at rest in order to influence external outcomes or hide activity, thus threatening the integrity of the data. By manipulating stored data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, and decision making.

Name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
Description: Adversaries may alter data en route to storage or other systems in order to manipulate external outcomes or hide activity, thus threatening the integrity of the data. By manipulating transmitted data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, and decision making.

Name: Runtime Data Manipulation
Description: Adversaries may modify systems in order to manipulate the data as it is accessed and displayed to an end user, thus threatening the integrity of the data. By manipulating runtime data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, and decision making.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: Adversaries may obfuscate command and control traffic to make it more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware has used the .PNG file format for C2 communications.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware has retrieved stage 2 payloads as Bitmap images that use Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware can use junk data in the Base64 string for additional obfuscation.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware can insert pseudo-random characters into its network encryption setup.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware has used random identifier strings to obscure its C2 operations and result codes.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: The malware can masquerade its C2 traffic as legitimate Google Notifications HTTP requests.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware has used FakeTLS for session authentication.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware can encode binary data into a .PNG file for C2 communication.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: The malware can embed C2 responses in the source code of a fake Flickr webpage.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware C2 data attempted to appear as benign XML related to .NET assemblies or as a faux JSON blob.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware masqueraded its network traffic as the Orion Improvement Program (OIP) protocol.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware added junk bytes to its C2 over HTTP.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: The malware has hashed a string containing system information prior to exfiltration via POST requests.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware can process steganographic images attached to email messages to send and receive C2 commands. the malware can also embed additional messages within BMP images to communicate with the malware operator.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: The malware has used encoded data within subdomains as AES ciphertext to communicate from the host to the C2.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware samples were found to be highly obfuscated with junk code.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware can send randomly-generated data as part of its C2 communication.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware added junk data to outgoing UDP packets to peer implants.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware mimics HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual messages in the Cookie and Set-Cookie headers of the HTTP requests.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware has obfuscated the FML.dll with 200MB of junk data.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware is controlled via commands that are embedded into PDFs and JPGs using steganographic methods.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware uses custom SSL libraries to impersonate SSL in C2 traffic.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware can generate a sequence of dummy HTTP C2 requests to obscure traffic.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware can mimic HTTP protocol with custom HTTP “verbs” HIDE, ZVVP, and NOP.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware is controlled via commands that are appended to image files.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware  can pad C2 messages with random generated values.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware has used decoy traffic to surround its malicious network traffic to avoid detection.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: The malware can send compressed and obfuscated packets to C2.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: The malware may obfuscate portions of the initial C2 handshake.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers. Additionally, some variants of the malware use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server.

Name: Steganography
Description: When the malware command and control is operating over HTTP or HTTPS, Duqu uploads data to its controller by appending it to a blank JPG file.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.

Name: Steganography
Description: The malware can use steganography to hide malicious code downloaded to the victim.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware can mimic the HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual data in either an HTTP header, URI parameter, the transaction body, or appending it to the URI.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The malware has used byte randomization to obscure its behavior.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware generates a false TLS handshake using a public certificate to disguise C2 network communications.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The malware uses a FakeTLS method during C2.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The threat actors malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, potentially evading SSL traffic inspection/decryption.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: The threat actors used a FakeTLS session for C2 communications.

Name: Steganography
Description: The threat actors has used steganography to hide its C2 communications.

Name: Junk Data
Description: The threat actors added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.

Name: Data Obfuscation
Description: During the attack, threat actors encrypted IP addresses used for "Agent" proxy hops with RC4.

Name: Steganography
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used steganography to hide the communications between the implants and their C&C servers.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: During the attack, the threat actors frequently configured the URL endpoints of their stealthy passive backdoor LOWKEY.PASSIVE to masquerade as normal web application traffic on an infected server.

Name: Junk Data
Description: Adversaries may add junk data to protocols used for command and control to make detection more difficult. By adding random or meaningless data to the protocols used for command and control, adversaries can prevent trivial methods for decoding, deciphering, or otherwise analyzing the traffic. Examples may include appending/prepending data with junk characters or writing junk characters between significant characters.

Name: Steganography
Description: Adversaries may use steganographic techniques to hide command and control traffic to make detection efforts more difficult. Steganographic techniques can be used to hide data in digital messages that are transferred between systems. This hidden information can be used for command and control of compromised systems. In some cases, the passing of files embedded using steganography, such as image or document files, can be used for command and control.

Name: Protocol Impersonation
Description: Adversaries may impersonate legitimate protocols or web service traffic to disguise command and control activity and thwart analysis efforts. By impersonating legitimate protocols or web services, adversaries can make their command and control traffic blend in with legitimate network traffic.

Name: Data Staged
Description: Adversaries may stage collected data in a central location or directory prior to Exfiltration. Data may be kept in separate files or combined into one file through techniques such as Archive Collected Data. Interactive command shells may be used, and common functionality within cmd and bash may be used to copy data into a staging location.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has stored the collected system files in a working directory.

Name: Remote Data Staging
Description: The malware has copied files to a remote machine infected with the malware or another backdoor.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can temporarily store files in a hidden directory on the local host.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware stores all collected information in a single file before exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has used tmp files to stage gathered information.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware collects files matching certain criteria from the victim and stores them in a local directory for later exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can store copied files in a specific directory prior to exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can create directories to store plugin output and stage data for exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can store harvested data in a custom database under the %TEMP% directory.

Description: The malware has stored information in folders named `U1` and `U2` prior to exfiltration.

Description: The malware has stored collected data under `%<malware_execution_folder>%\\CrashLog.txt`.

Description: The malware identifies files with certain extensions and copies them to a directory in the user's profile.

Description: The malware copies files from removable drives to C:\system.

Description: Data captured by the malware is placed in a temporary file under a directory named "memdump".

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can stage data prior to exfiltration in %APPDATA%\Microsoft\UserSettingand %APPDATA%\Microsoft\UserSetting\MediaCache.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can use a file exfiltration tool to copy files to C:\ProgramData\Adobe\tempprior to exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has stored stolen emails and other data into new folders prior to exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware creates various subdirectories under %Temp%\reports\%and copies files to those subdirectories. It also creates a folder at C:\Users\<Username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\storeto store screenshot JPEG files.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware creates a directory, %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\SKC\, which is used to store collected log files.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware can stage stolen browser data in `C:\\Windows\\Temp\\cup.tmp` and keylogger data in `C:\\Windows\\Temp\\Report.06E17A5A-7325-4325-8E5D-E172EBA7FC5BK`.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware stages collected data in a text file.

Description: The malware has saved information to a random temp file before exfil.

Description: The malware has stored collected information in the Application Data directory on a compromised host.

Description: The malware can copy specific files, webcam captures, and screenshots to local directories.

Description: The malware has the ability to write collected data to a file created in the ./LOGSdirectory.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has temporarily stored collected information to the files `“%AppData%\{Unique Identifier}\HOSTRURKLSR”` and `“%AppData%\{Unique Identifier}\NEWERSSEMP”`.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has saved files prior to upload from a compromised host to folders beginning with the characters `a9850d2f`.

Description: The malware can place retrieved files into a destination directory.

Description: The malware stores files and logs in a folder on the local drive.

Description: The malware can write captured SSH connection credentials to a file under the /var/rundirectory with a .pidextension for exfiltration.

Description: The malware stages command output and collected data in files before exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware creates a file in AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\Explorerand stores all harvested data in that file.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has stored keystrokes and screenshots within the %temp%\GoogleChrome, %temp%\Downloads, and %temp%\TrendMicroUpdatedirectories.

Description: The malware has the ability to create files in a TEMP folder to act as a database to store information.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: Modules can be pushed to and executed by the malware that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.

Description: The malware can save collected data to disk, different file formats, and network shares.

Description: The malware can stage local data in the Windows Registry.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has staged stolen files in the C:\AMD\Tempdirectory.

Description: The malware can store captured system information locally prior to exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware stores the gathered data from the machine in .db files and .bmp files under four separate locations.

Description: The malware creates a base directory that contains the files and folders that are collected.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware has created a working folder for collected files that it sends to the C2 server.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The malware copies documents under 15MB found on the victim system to is the user's %temp%\SMB\folder. It also copies files from USB devices to a predefined directory.

Description: The malware stores output from command execution in a .dat file in the %TEMP% directory.

Name: Remote Data Staging
Description: The threat actors has staged data on remote MSP systems or other victim networks prior to exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The threat actors stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.

Name: Data Staged
Description: The threat actors has collected and staged credentials and network enumeration information, using  the networkdll and psfin the malware modules.

Name: Remote Data Staging
Description: The threat actors has moved staged encrypted archives to Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with the malware prior to exfiltration.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The threat actors has locally staged encrypted archives for later exfiltration efforts.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: The threat actors has aggregated collected credentials in text files before exfiltrating.

Description: The threat actors has created staging folders in directories that were infrequently used by legitimate users or processes.

Description: The threat actors has created a directory named "out" in the user's %AppData% folder and copied files to it.

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: During the attack, stolen data was copied into a text file using the format `From <COMPUTER-NAME> (<Month>-<Day> <Hour>-<Minute>-<Second>).txt` prior to compression, encoding, and exfiltration.

Name: Remote Data Staging
Description: During the attack, threat actors copied files to company web servers and subsequently downloaded them.

Name: Local Data Staging

Name: Local Data Staging

Name: Local Data Staging
Description: Adversaries may stage collected data in a central location or directory on the local system prior to Exfiltration. Data may be kept in separate files or combined into one file through techniques such as Archive Collected Data. Interactive command shells may be used, and common functionality within cmd and bash may be used to copy data into a staging location.

Name: Remote Data Staging
Description: Adversaries may stage data collected from multiple systems in a central location or directory on one system prior to Exfiltration. Data may be kept in separate files or combined into one file through techniques such as Archive Collected Data. Interactive command shells may be used, and common functionality within cmd and bash may be used to copy data into a staging location.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: An adversary may exfiltrate data in fixed size chunks instead of whole files or limit packet sizes below certain thresholds. This approach may be used to avoid triggering network data transfer threshold alerts.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware "chunker" overlay supports splitting large files in smaller chunks during upload to circumvent size limits.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware can upload a file via HTTP POST response to the C2 split into 102,400-byte portions. the malware can also download data from the C2 which is split into 81,920-byte portions.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware uploads data in 2048-byte chunks.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware can break large files of interest into smaller chunks to prepare them for exfiltration.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware supports custom chunk sizes used to upload/download files.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware can exfiltrate data to the C2 server in 27-character chunks.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware can split the data to be exilftrated into chunks that will fit in subdomains of DNS queries.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware will break large data sets into smaller chunks for exfiltration.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware exfiltrates data in compressed chunks if a message is larger than 4096 bytes .

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The malware has divided files if the size is 0x1000000 bytes or more.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The threat actors actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The threat actors has split archived files into multiple parts to bypass a 5MB limit.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: The threat actors has split archived exfiltration files into chunks smaller than 1MB.

Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Description: During the attack, the threat actors limited the malware's bandwidth setting during exfiltration.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware uses a function named is_debuggingto perform anti-debugging logic. The function invokes sysctlchecking the returned value of P_TRACED. the malware also calls ptracewith the PTRACE_DENY_ATTACHflag to prevent debugging.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware has used `is_debugger_present` as part of its environmental checks.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware can check for debugging tools.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware can search for debugging tools on a compromised host.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware can detect debuggers by using functions such as `DebuggerIsAttached` and `DebuggerIsLogging`. the malware can also detect profilers by verifying the `COR_ENABLE_PROFILING` environment variable is present and active.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware can use `IsDebuggerPresent` to detect whether a debugger is present on a victim.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware can search for tools used in static analysis.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: The malware dropper can check system flags, CPU registers, CPU instructions, process timing, system libraries, and APIs to determine if a debugger is present.

Name: Debugger Evasion
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used tools that used the `IsDebuggerPresent` call to detect debuggers.

Name: Defacement
Description: Adversaries may modify visual content available internally or externally to an enterprise network, thus affecting the integrity of the original content. Reasons for Defacement include delivering messaging, intimidation, or claiming (possibly false) credit for an intrusion. Disturbing or offensive images may be used as a part of Defacement in order to cause user discomfort, or to pressure compliance with accompanying messages.

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: The malware can change both the desktop wallpaper and the lock screen image to a custom image.

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: After encryption, the malware will capture the desktop background window, set the background color to black, and change the desktop wallpaper to a newly created bitmap image with the text “All your files are encrypted! For more information see “README-FOR-DECRYPT.txt".

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: The malware can change the desktop wallpaper on compromised hosts.

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: The malware has set the desktop wallpaper on victims' machines to display a ransom note.

Name: External Defacement
Description: The threat actors defaced approximately 15,000 websites belonging to Georgian government, non-government, and private sector organizations in 2019.

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: The threat actors replaced the background wallpaper of systems with a threatening image after rendering the system unbootable with a Disk Structure Wipe.

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: The threat actors has left taunting images and messages on the victims' desktops as proof of system access.

Name: Internal Defacement
Description: An adversary may deface systems internal to an organization in an attempt to intimidate or mislead users, thus discrediting the integrity of the systems. This may take the form of modifications to internal websites, or directly to user systems with the replacement of the desktop wallpaper. Disturbing or offensive images may be used as a part of Internal Defacement in order to cause user discomfort, or to pressure compliance with accompanying messages. Since internally defacing systems exposes an adversary's presence, it often takes place after other intrusion goals have been accomplished.

Name: External Defacement
Description: An adversary may deface systems external to an organization in an attempt to deliver messaging, intimidate, or otherwise mislead an organization or users. External Defacement may ultimately cause users to distrust the systems and to question/discredit the system’s integrity. Externally-facing websites are a common victim of defacement; often targeted by adversary and hacktivist groups in order to push a political message or spread propaganda. External Defacement may be used as a catalyst to trigger events, or as a response to actions taken by an organization or government. Similarly, website defacement may also be used as setup, or a precursor, for future attacks such as Drive-by Compromise.

Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Description: Adversaries may use Obfuscated Files or Information to hide artifacts of an intrusion from analysis. They may require separate mechanisms to decode or deobfuscate that information depending on how they intend to use it. Methods for doing that include built-in functionality of malware or by using utilities present on the system.
