Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used the DUSTPAN loader to decrypt embedded payloads.

Name: Deploy Container
Description: Adversaries may deploy a container into an environment to facilitate execution or evade defenses. In some cases, adversaries may deploy a new container to execute processes associated with a particular image or deployment, such as processes that execute or download malware. In others, an adversary may deploy a new container configured without network rules, user limitations, etc. to bypass existing defenses within the environment.

Name: Deploy Container
Description: The malware can deploy a pod that mounts its node’s root file system, then execute a command to create a reverse shell on the node.

Name: Deploy Container
Description: The malware was run through a deployed Ubuntu container.

Name: Deploy Container
Description: The malware was run through a deployed container.

Name: Deploy Container
Description: The threat actors has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution. the threat actors has also transferred cryptocurrency mining software to Kubernetes clusters discovered within local IP address ranges.

Name: Develop Capabilities
Description: Adversaries may build capabilities that can be used during targeting. Rather than purchasing, freely downloading, or stealing capabilities, adversaries may develop their own capabilities in-house. This is the process of identifying development requirements and building solutions such as malware, exploits, and self-signed certificates. Adversaries may develop capabilities to support their operations throughout numerous phases of the adversary lifecycle.

Name: Malware
Description: Adversaries may develop malware and malware components that can be used during targeting. Building malicious software can include the development of payloads, droppers, post-compromise tools, backdoors (including backdoored images), packers, C2 protocols, and the creation of infected removable media. Adversaries may develop malware to support their operations, creating a means for maintaining control of remote machines, evading defenses, and executing post-compromise behaviors.

Name: Code Signing Certificates
Description: Adversaries may create self-signed code signing certificates that can be used during targeting. Code signing is the process of digitally signing executables and scripts to confirm the software author and guarantee that the code has not been altered or corrupted. Code signing provides a level of authenticity for a program from the developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with. Users and/or security tools may trust a signed piece of code more than an unsigned piece of code even if they don't know who issued the certificate or who the author is.

Name: Digital Certificates
Description: Adversaries may create self-signed SSL/TLS certificates that can be used during targeting. SSL/TLS certificates are designed to instill trust. They include information about the key, information about its owner's identity, and the digital signature of an entity that has verified the certificate's contents are correct. If the signature is valid, and the person examining the certificate trusts the signer, then they know they can use that key to communicate with its owner. In the case of self-signing, digital certificates will lack the element of trust associated with the signature of a third-party certificate authority (CA).

Name: Exploits
Description: Adversaries may develop exploits that can be used during targeting. An exploit takes advantage of a bug or vulnerability in order to cause unintended or unanticipated behavior to occur on computer hardware or software. Rather than finding/modifying exploits from online or purchasing them from exploit vendors, an adversary may develop their own exploits. Adversaries may use information acquired via Vulnerabilities to focus exploit development efforts. As part of the exploit development process, adversaries may uncover exploitable vulnerabilities through methods such as fuzzing and patch analysis.

Name: Direct Volume Access
Description: Adversaries may directly access a volume to bypass file access controls and file system monitoring. Windows allows programs to have direct access to logical volumes. Programs with direct access may read and write files directly from the drive by analyzing file system data structures. This technique bypasses Windows file access controls as well as file system monitoring tools.

Name: Disk Wipe
Description: Adversaries may wipe or corrupt raw disk data on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. With direct write access to a disk, adversaries may attempt to overwrite portions of disk data. Adversaries may opt to wipe arbitrary portions of disk data and/or wipe disk structures like the master boot record (MBR). A complete wipe of all disk sectors may be attempted.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware can overwrite the Master Book Record (MBR) on victim systems with a malicious 16-bit bootloader.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The malware can overwrite sectors of a victim host's hard drive at periodic offsets.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware can wipe the master boot record of an infected computer.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The malware can wipe the accessible physical or logical drives of the infected machine.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware has been seen overwriting features of disk structure such as the MBR.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware was used in the malware to help overwrite components of disk structure like the MBR and disk partitions.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The malware has been used to directly access the hard disk to help overwrite arbitrarily sized portions of disk content.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The malware can wipe deleted data from all drives using cipher.exe.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware overwrites the first sector of the Master Boot Record with “0x00”.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware has the ability to corrupt disk partitions, damage the Master Boot Record (MBR), and overwrite the Master File Table (MFT) of all available physical drives.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The malware has the ability to corrupt disk partitions and obtain raw disk access to destroy data.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The malware has the ability to destroy information about a physical drive's partitions including the MBR, GPT, and partition entries.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The malware has the ability to wipe VM snapshots on compromised networks.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The threat actors has used the malware KillDisk component to corrupt the infected system's master boot record.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The threat actors malware SHARPKNOT overwrites and deletes the Master Boot Record (MBR) on the victim's machine and has possessed MBR wiper malware since at least 2009.

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: The threat actors has used malware like WhiskeyAlfa to overwrite the first 64MB of every drive with a mix of static and random buffers. A similar process is then used to wipe content in logical drives and, finally, attempt to wipe every byte of every sector on every drive. WhiskeyBravo can be used to overwrite the first 4.9MB of physical drives. WhiskeyDelta can overwrite the first 132MB or 1.5MB of each drive with random data from heap memory.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The threat actors has used a custom MBR wiper named BOOTWRECK to render systems inoperable.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: The threat actors has access to destructive malware that is capable of overwriting a machine's Master Boot Record (MBR).

Name: Disk Content Wipe
Description: Adversaries may erase the contents of storage devices on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

Name: Disk Structure Wipe
Description: Adversaries may corrupt or wipe the disk data structures on a hard drive necessary to boot a system; targeting specific critical systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources.

Name: Domain Policy Modification
Description: Adversaries may modify the configuration settings of a domain to evade defenses and/or escalate privileges in domain environments. Domains provide a centralized means of managing how computer resources (ex: computers, user accounts) can act, and interact with each other, on a network. The policy of the domain also includes configuration settings that may apply between domains in a multi-domain/forest environment. Modifications to domain settings may include altering domain Group Policy Objects (GPOs) or changing trust settings for domains, including federation trusts.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: The malware has been deployed using the Default Domain Group Policy Object from an Active Directory Domain Controller.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: The malware can use group policy to push a scheduled task from the AD to all network machines.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: The malware has the ability to deploy through an infected system's default domain policy.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: The malware can use New-GPOImmediateTaskto modify a GPO that will install and execute a malicious Scheduled Task/Job.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: The malware can modify the GPO to evade detection.

Name: Domain Trust Modification
Description: The malware can create a backdoor by converting a domain to a federated domain which will be able to authenticate any user across the tenant. the malware can also modify DesktopSSO information.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: The threat actors has used Group Policy Objects to deploy batch scripts.

Name: Domain Trust Modification
Description: During the attack, the threat actors changed domain federation trust settings using Azure AD administrative permissions to configure the domain to accept authorization tokens signed by their own SAML signing certificate.

Name: Group Policy Modification
Description: Adversaries may modify Group Policy Objects (GPOs) to subvert the intended discretionary access controls for a domain, usually with the intention of escalating privileges on the domain. Group policy allows for centralized management of user and computer settings in Active Directory (AD). GPOs are containers for group policy settings made up of files stored within a predicable network path \<DOMAIN>\SYSVOL\<DOMAIN>\Policies\.

Name: Domain Trust Modification
Description: Adversaries may add new domain trusts or modify the properties of existing domain trusts to evade defenses and/or elevate privileges. Domain trust details, such as whether or not a domain is federated, allow authentication and authorization properties to apply between domains for the purpose of accessing shared resources. These trust objects may include accounts, credentials, and other authentication material applied to servers, tokens, and domains.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: Adversaries may attempt to gather information on domain trust relationships that may be used to identify lateral movement opportunities in Windows multi-domain/forest environments. Domain trusts provide a mechanism for a domain to allow access to resources based on the authentication procedures of another domain. Domain trusts allow the users of the trusted domain to access resources in the trusting domain. The information discovered may help the adversary conduct SID-History Injection, Pass the Ticket, and Kerberoasting. Domain trusts can be enumerated using the DSEnumerateDomainTrusts() Win32 API call, .NET methods, and LDAP. The Windows utility Nltest is known to be used by adversaries to enumerate domain trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can be used to gather information on domain trusts with dsquery * -filter "(objectClass=trustedDomain)" -attr *.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can gather information about domain trusts by utilizing the malware.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can gather information about domain trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can run nltest /domain_trusts /all_trustsfor domain trust discovery.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware has modules such as Get-NetDomainTrustand Get-NetForestTrustto enumerate domain and forest trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware has modules for enumerating domain trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware may be used to enumerate trusted domains by using commands such as nltest /domain_trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware has modules for enumerating domain trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can use LDAP queries and `nltest /domain_trusts` for domain trust discovery.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware has the ability to map domain trusts and identify misconfigurations for potential abuse.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can use the malware tools to obtain information about the domain.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The malware can gather information about organizational units (OUs) and domain trusts from Active Directory.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The threat actors has used a web shell to execute `nltest /trusted_domains` to identify trust relationships.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The threat actors has retrieved a list of trusted domains by using the malware.exe /domain_trusts.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The threat actors has used the malware to obtain information about domain controllers.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: The threat actors has nltest /domain_truststo identify domain trust relationships.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used the `Get-AcceptedDomain` PowerShell cmdlet to enumerate accepted domains through an Exchange Management Shell. They also used the malware to enumerate domains and to discover trust between federated domains.

Name: Domain Trust Discovery
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used the command `nltest /domain_trusts /all_trusts` to enumerate domain trusts.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing. With this technique, the user's web browser is typically targeted for exploitation, but adversaries may also use compromised websites for non-exploitation behavior such as acquiring Application Access Token.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware has infected victim machines through compromised websites and exploit kits.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware is typically bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology (VST) for Windows and macOS.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware has used compromised websites and Google Ads to bait victims into downloading its installer.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware has been spread through malicious advertisements on websites.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The malware spread through watering holes on popular sites by injecting JavaScript into the HTML body or a .jsfile.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used compromised websites to register custom URL schemes on a remote system.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has distributed Windows malware via drive-by downloads.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has infected victims using watering holes.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with the malware, the malware, and other malicious tools.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has distributed its malware via the RIG and SUNDOWN exploit kits, as well as online advertising network Yandex.Direct.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used watering hole attacks to deliver malicious versions of legitimate installers.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has conducted watering-hole attacks through media and magazine websites.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has distributed the malware through a fake blog website.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has infected victims using watering holes.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has infected victims using watering holes.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors delivered the malware and other malicious code to victims via a compromised legitimate website.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has performed watering hole attacks.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has compromised targets via strategic web compromise (SWC) utilizing a custom exploit kit.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors used embedded iframes on hotel login portals to redirect selected victims to download malware.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used watering hole attacks to gain access.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used watering hole attacks, often with zero-day exploits, to gain initial access to victims within a specific IP range.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has conducted watering holes schemes to gain initial access to victims.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors has compromised targets via strategic web compromise utilizing custom exploit kits.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: The threat actors performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used a watering hole attack on a popular software reseller to exploit then-zero-day Internet Explorer vulnerability CVE-2014-0322.

Name: Drive-by Compromise
Description: During the attack, UNC3890 actors likely established a watering hole that was hosted on a login page of a legitimate Israeli shipping company that was active until at least November 2021.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: Adversaries may dynamically establish connections to command and control infrastructure to evade common detections and remediations. This may be achieved by using malware that shares a common algorithm with the infrastructure the adversary uses to receive the malware's communications. These calculations can be used to dynamically adjust parameters such as the domain name, IP address, or port number the malware uses for command and control.

Name: Fast Flux DNS
Description: The malware has used a fast flux DNS for C2 IP resolution.

Name: Fast Flux DNS
Description: The malware operators have used dynamic DNS to mask the true location of their C2 behind rapidly changing IP addresses.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has used a DGA to generate domain names for C2.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware has connected to a signalization server that provides a URL and port, and then the malware sends a GET request to that URL to establish C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use a custom DGA to generate a subdomain for C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can send DNS C2 communications using a unique domain generation algorithm.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware uses a DGA that is based on the day of the month for C2 servers.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware dynamically resolved C2 infrastructure for randomly-generated subdomains within a parent domain.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware has resolved the malware C2 server IP addresses by either converting Bitcoin blockchain transaction data to specific octets, or accessing IP addresses directly within the Namecoin blockchain.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use domain generation algorithms in C2 communication.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware uses a DGA to derive command and control URLs from a word list.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can provide DGA for C2 servers through the use of random URL strings that change every 12 hours.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware can use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and port number pair to connect to for C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use DGA to generate new Twitter URLs for C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use hardcoded domains as an input for domain generation algorithms.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware has forged POST strings with a random choice from a list of possibilities including "forum", "php", "view", etc. while making connection with the C2, hindering detection efforts.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use a DGA for hiding C2 addresses, including use of an algorithm with a user-specific key that changes daily.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware can use dynamic DNS domain names in C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has used a DGA to generate a domain name for C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has used the DynDNS service and a DGA based on the Dogecoin blockchain to generate C2 domains.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has used a DGA to generate a domain name for C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has used a DGA that seeds with the current UTC victim system date to generate domains.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use a DGA for Fallback Channels, domains are generated by concatenating words from lists.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can use a DGA for Fallback Channels if communications with the primary command and control server are lost.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The malware has used a dynamic DNS service for C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware can implement DGA using the current date as a seed variable.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware uses a DGA to communicate with command and control servers.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has used a DGA in C2 communications.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The malware has the ability to use a DGA for C2 communications.

Name: Fast Flux DNS
Description: The malware has used fast flux DNS for its C2.

Name: Fast Flux DNS
Description: The threat actors has used dynamic DNS service providers to host malicious domains.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The threat actors has used dynamic DNS services to set up C2.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The threat actors has used a DGA to generate URLs from executed macros.

Name: Fast Flux DNS
Description: The threat actors has used fast flux to mask botnets by distributing payloads across multiple IPs.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The threat actors has incorporated dynamic DNS domains in its infrastructure.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: The threat actors has used DDNS for C2 communications.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: The threat actors has used DGAs to change their C2 servers monthly.

Name: DNS Calculation
Description: The threat actors has used multiple variants of DNS Calculation including multiplying the first two octets of an IP address and adding the third octet to that value in order to get a resulting command and control port.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used dynamic DNS resolution to construct and resolve to randomly-generated subdomains for C2.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: For the attack, the threat actors used dynamic DNS services, including Duck DNS and DNS Exit, as part of their C2 infrastructure.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: For the attack, the threat actors used dynamic DNS domains from a variety of free providers, including No-IP, Oray, and 3322.

Name: Dynamic Resolution
Description: During the attack, threat actors used dynamic DNS services for C2.

Name: Fast Flux DNS
Description: Adversaries may use Fast Flux DNS to hide a command and control channel behind an array of rapidly changing IP addresses linked to a single domain resolution. This technique uses a fully qualified domain name, with multiple IP addresses assigned to it which are swapped with high frequency, using a combination of round robin IP addressing and short Time-To-Live (TTL) for a DNS resource record.

Name: Domain Generation Algorithms
Description: Adversaries may make use of Domain Generation Algorithms (DGAs) to dynamically identify a destination domain for command and control traffic rather than relying on a list of static IP addresses or domains. This has the advantage of making it much harder for defenders to block, track, or take over the command and control channel, as there potentially could be thousands of domains that malware can check for instructions.

Name: DNS Calculation
Description: Adversaries may perform calculations on addresses returned in DNS results to determine which port and IP address to use for command and control, rather than relying on a predetermined port number or the actual returned IP address. A IP and/or port number calculation can be used to bypass egress filtering on a C2 channel.

Name: Email Collection
Description: Adversaries may target user email to collect sensitive information. Emails may contain sensitive data, including trade secrets or personal information, that can prove valuable to adversaries. Adversaries can collect or forward email from mail servers or clients.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The malware can collect sensitive mailing information from Exchange servers, including credentials and the domain certificate of an enterprise.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware searches through Outlook files and directories (e.g., inbox, sent, templates, drafts, archives, etc.).

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: Some the malware samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware can target and steal locally stored emails to support thread hijacking phishing campaigns.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware can interact with a victim’s Outlook session and look through folders and emails.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware can parse e-mails on a target machine.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The malware can be used for searching through email in Exchange and Office 365 environments.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The malware collects Exchange emails matching rules specified in its configuration.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware can harvest data from mail clients.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware has the ability to collect emails on a target system.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware has been observed leveraging a module that scrapes email data from Outlook.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware contains a command to collect and exfiltrate emails from Outlook.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware searches for Microsoft Outlook data files with extensions .pst and .ost for collection and exfiltration.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The malware searches recursively for Outlook personal storage tables (PST) files within user directories and sends them back to the C2 server.

Name: Email Forwarding Rule
Description: The threat actors has set up auto forwarding rules on compromised e-mail accounts.

Name: Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has exfiltrated entire mailboxes from compromised accounts.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has exported emails from compromised Exchange servers including through use of the cmdlet `New-MailboxExportRequest.`

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has collected .PST archives.

Name: Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has compromised email credentials in order to steal sensitive data.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors used a tool called MailSniper to search through the Exchange server mailboxes for keywords.

Name: Email Forwarding Rule
Description: The threat actors has set an Office 365 tenant level mail transport rule to send all mail in and out of the targeted organization to the newly created account.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has used tools such as the MailFetch mail crawler to collect victim emails (excluding spam) from online services via IMAP.

Name: Email Forwarding Rule
Description: The threat actors has set auto-forward rules on victim's e-mail accounts.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has used compromised credentials and a .NET tool to dump data from Microsoft Exchange mailboxes.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has used web shells to export mailbox data.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has accessed and hijacked online email communications using stolen credentials.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has accessed email accounts using Outlook Web Access.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has harvested data from remote mailboxes including through execution of \\<hostname>\c$\Users\<username>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Outlook*.ost.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description:
The threat actors has harvested data from victim's e-mail including through execution of wmic /node:<ip> process call create "cmd /c copy c:\Users\<username>\<path>\backup.pst c:\windows\temp\backup.pst" copy "i:\<path>\<username>\My Documents\<filename>.pst"
copy.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has collected emails from targeted mailboxes within a compromised Azure AD tenant.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors has collected emails from victim Microsoft Exchange servers.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: The threat actors uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. MAPIGET steals email still on Exchange servers that has not yet been archived.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: The threat actors uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. GETMAIL extracts emails from archived Outlook .pst files.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: During the attack, the threat actors collected emails from specific individuals, such as executives and IT staff, using `New-MailboxExportRequest` followed by `Get-MailboxExportRequest`.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: During the attack, threat actors used RAT malware to exfiltrate email archives.

Name: Local Email Collection
Description: Adversaries may target user email on local systems to collect sensitive information. Files containing email data can be acquired from a user’s local system, such as Outlook storage or cache files.

Name: Remote Email Collection
Description: Adversaries may target an Exchange server, Office 365, or Google Workspace to collect sensitive information. Adversaries may leverage a user's credentials and interact directly with the Exchange server to acquire information from within a network. Adversaries may also access externally facing Exchange services, Office 365, or Google Workspace to access email using credentials or access tokens. Tools such as MailSniper can be used to automate searches for specific keywords.

Name: Email Forwarding Rule
Description: Adversaries may setup email forwarding rules to collect sensitive information. Adversaries may abuse email-forwarding rules to monitor the activities of a victim, steal information, and further gain intelligence on the victim or the victim’s organization to use as part of further exploits or operations. Furthermore, email forwarding rules can allow adversaries to maintain persistent access to victim's emails even after compromised credentials are reset by administrators. Most email clients allow users to create inbox rules for various email functions, including forwarding to a different recipient. These rules may be created through a local email application, a web interface, or by command-line interface. Messages can be forwarded to internal or external recipients, and there are no restrictions limiting the extent of this rule. Administrators may also create forwarding rules for user accounts with the same considerations and outcomes.

Name: Encrypted Channel
Description: Adversaries may employ a known encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Despite the use of a secure algorithm, these implementations may be vulnerable to reverse engineering if secret keys are encoded and/or generated within malware samples/configuration files.

Name: Symmetric Cryptography
Description: Adversaries may employ a known symmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Symmetric encryption algorithms use the same key for plaintext encryption and ciphertext decryption. Common symmetric encryption algorithms include AES, DES, 3DES, Blowfish, and RC4.

Name: Asymmetric Cryptography
Description: Adversaries may employ a known asymmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Asymmetric cryptography, also known as public key cryptography, uses a keypair per party: one public that can be freely distributed, and one private. Due to how the keys are generated, the sender encrypts data with the receiver’s public key and the receiver decrypts the data with their private key. This ensures that only the intended recipient can read the encrypted data. Common public key encryption algorithms include RSA and ElGamal.

Name: Endpoint Denial of Service
Description: Adversaries may perform Endpoint Denial of Service (DoS) attacks to degrade or block the availability of services to users. Endpoint DoS can be performed by exhausting the system resources those services are hosted on or exploiting the system to cause a persistent crash condition. Example services include websites, email services, DNS, and web-based applications. Adversaries have been observed conducting DoS attacks for political purposes and to support other malicious activities, including distraction, hacktivism, and extortion.

Name: Endpoint Denial of Service
Description: The malware has a feature to perform SYN flood attack on a host.

Name: Endpoint Denial of Service
Description: The malware has the capability to use a Denial of Service module.

Name: Application or System Exploitation
Description: The malware uses a custom DoS tool that leverages CVE-2015-5374 and targets hardcoded IP addresses of Siemens SIPROTEC devices.

Name: Endpoint Denial of Service
Description: The threat actors temporarily disrupted service to Georgian government, non-government, and private sector websites after compromising a Georgian web hosting provider in 2019.

Name: OS Exhaustion Flood
Description: Adversaries may launch a denial of service (DoS) attack targeting an endpoint's operating system (OS). A system's OS is responsible for managing the finite resources as well as preventing the entire system from being overwhelmed by excessive demands on its capacity. These attacks do not need to exhaust the actual resources on a system; the attacks may simply exhaust the limits and available resources that an OS self-imposes.

Name: Service Exhaustion Flood
Description: Adversaries may target the different network services provided by systems to conduct a denial of service (DoS). Adversaries often target the availability of DNS and web services, however others have been targeted as well. Web server software can be attacked through a variety of means, some of which apply generally while others are specific to the software being used to provide the service.

Name: Application Exhaustion Flood
Description: Adversaries may target resource intensive features of applications to cause a denial of service (DoS), denying availability to those applications. For example, specific features in web applications may be highly resource intensive. Repeated requests to those features may be able to exhaust system resources and deny access to the application or the server itself.

Name: Application or System Exploitation
Description: Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities that can cause an application or system to crash and deny availability to users. Some systems may automatically restart critical applications and services when crashes occur, but they can likely be re-exploited to cause a persistent denial of service (DoS) condition.

Name: Escape to Host
Description: Adversaries may break out of a container to gain access to the underlying host. This can allow an adversary access to other containerized resources from the host level or to the host itself. In principle, containerized resources should provide a clear separation of application functionality and be isolated from the host environment.

Name: Escape to Host
Description: The malware maps the host’s C drive to the container by creating a global symbolic link to the host through the calling of NtSetInformationSymbolicLink.

Name: Escape to Host
Description: The malware can gain a reverse shell on a host node by mounting the Kubernetes hostPath.

Name: Escape to Host
Description: The malware has used the BOtB tool that can break out of containers.

Name: Escape to Host
Description: The malware’s container was configured to bind the host root directory.

Name: Escape to Host
Description: The threat actors has deployed privileged containers that mount the filesystem of victim machine.

Name: Establish Accounts
Description: Adversaries may create and cultivate accounts with services that can be used during targeting. Adversaries can create accounts that can be used to build a persona to further operations. Persona development consists of the development of public information, presence, history and appropriate affiliations. This development could be applied to social media, website, or other publicly available information that could be referenced and scrutinized for legitimacy over the course of an operation using that persona or identity.

Name: Social Media Accounts
Description: Adversaries may create and cultivate social media accounts that can be used during targeting. Adversaries can create social media accounts that can be used to build a persona to further operations. Persona development consists of the development of public information, presence, history and appropriate affiliations.

Name: Email Accounts
Description: Adversaries may create email accounts that can be used during targeting. Adversaries can use accounts created with email providers to further their operations, such as leveraging them to conduct Phishing for Information or Phishing. Adversaries may also take steps to cultivate a persona around the email account, such as through use of Social Media Accounts, to increase the chance of success of follow-on behaviors. Created email accounts can also be used in the acquisition of infrastructure (ex: Domains).

Name: Event Triggered Execution
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges using system mechanisms that trigger execution based on specific events. Various operating systems have means to monitor and subscribe to events such as logons or other user activity such as running specific applications/binaries.

Name: Netsh Helper DLL
Description: The malware can be used as a persistence proxy technique to execute a helper DLL when netsh.exe is executed.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware registered a WMI event subscription consumer called "hard_disk_stat" to establish persistence.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware can use a WMI script to achieve persistence.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware  can perform COM hijacking by setting the path to itself to the `HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command` key with a `DelegateExecute` parameter.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware has the ability to use WMI for persistence.

Name: AppInit DLLs
Description: If a victim meets certain criteria, the malware uses the AppInit_DLL functionality to achieve persistence by ensuring that every user mode process that is spawned will load its malicious DLL, ResN32.dll. It does this by creating the following Registry keys: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\AppInit_DLLs – %APPDATA%\Intel\ResN32.dlland HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\LoadAppInit_DLLs – 0x1.

Name: Application Shimming
Description: The malware has installed shim databases in the AppPatchfolder.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware uses an event filter in WMI code to execute a previously dropped executable shortly after system startup.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware has created the `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\CLSID\{E6D34FFC-AD32-4d6a-934C-D387FA873A19}` Registry key for persistence.

Name: Image File Execution Options Injection
Description: The malware created an Image File Execution Options (IFEO) Debugger registry value for the process dllhost.exeto trigger the installation of the malware.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware can create a WMI Event to execute a payload for persistence.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware can add a CLSID key for payload execution through `Registry.CurrentUser.CreateSubKey("Software\\Classes\\CLSID\\{" + clsid + "}\\InProcServer32")`.

Name: Change Default File Association
Description: The malware can conduct an image hijack of an `.msc` file extension as part of its UAC bypass process.

Name: Image File Execution Options Injection
Description: The malware has the ability to use image file execution options for persistence if it detects it is running with admin privileges on a Windows version newer than Windows 7.

Name: Application Shimming
Description: The malware has the ability to use application shimming for persistence if it detects it is running as admin on Windows XP or 7, by creating a shim database to patch services.exe.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware can persist using a WMI consumer that is launched every time a process named WINWORD.EXE is started.

Name: AppInit DLLs
Description: The malware can insert itself into the address space of other applications using the AppInit DLL Registry key.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware has the ability to persist on a system using WMI events.

Name: Application Shimming
Description: The malware has used a malicious shim database to maintain persistence.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware has created the `HKCU\\Software\\Classes\\CLSID\\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\\InprocServer32` Registry key for persistence.

Name: AppCert DLLs
Description: The malware can establish using a AppCertDLLs Registry key.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware can use WMI for persistence.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The malware uses a WMI event subscription to establish persistence.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware uses COM hijacking as a method of persistence.

Name: Unix Shell Configuration Modification
Description: The malware maintains persistence on an infected machine through rc.local and .bashrc files.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware has modified ComSysApp service to load the malicious DLL payload.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware has used COM hijacking to establish persistence by hijacking a class named MMDeviceEnumerator and also by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object ({3543619C-D563-43f7-95EA-4DA7E1CC396A}).

Name: Unix Shell Configuration Modification
Description: The malware can establish persistence on a compromised host through modifying the `profile`, `login`, and run command (rc) files associated with the `bash`, `csh`, and `tcsh` shells.

Name: Screensaver
Description: The malware can establish persistence through the system screensaver by configuring it to execute the malware.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware can use COM hijacking to establish persistence.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The malware can leverage WMI debugging to remotely replace binaries like sethc.exe, Utilman.exe, and Magnify.exe with cmd.exe.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware samples have been seen which hijack COM objects for persistence by replacing the path to shell32.dll in registry location HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32.

Name: AppInit DLLs
Description: Some variants of the malware use AppInit_DLLs to achieve persistence by creating the following Registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows "AppInit_DLLs"="pserver32.dll"

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The malware has been seen persisting via COM hijacking through replacement of the COM object for MruPidlList {42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}or Microsoft WBEM New Event Subsystem {F3130CDB-AA52-4C3A-AB32-85FFC23AF9C1}depending on the system's CPU architecture.

Name: Installer Packages
Description: During the malware's installation process, it uses `postinstall` scripts to extract a hidden plist from the application's `/Resources` folder and execute the `plist` file as a Launch Daemon with elevated permissions.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: Some variants of the malware achieve persistence by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.

Name: PowerShell Profile
Description: The threat actors has used PowerShell profiles to maintain persistence on an infected machine.

Name: Image File Execution Options Injection
Description: The threat actors has modified and added entries within HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Optionsto maintain persistence.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors's custom ORat tool uses a WMI event consumer to maintain persistence.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has established persistence through the use of a WMI event subscription combined with unusual living-off-the-land binaries such as `cdb.exe`.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has used WMI for persistence.

Name: Change Default File Association
Description: The threat actors has a HWP document stealer module which changes the default program association in the registry to open HWP documents.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The threat actors has used sticky keys to launch a command prompt.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

Name: Application Shimming
Description: The threat actors has used application shim databases for persistence.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The threat actors has used the sticky-keys technique to bypass the RDP login screen on remote systems during intrusions.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has used mofcomp.exe to establish WMI Event Subscription persistence mechanisms configured from a *.mof file.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The threat actors actors have been known to use the Sticky Keys replacement within RDP sessions to obtain persistence.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The threat actors leveraged sticky keys to establish persistence.

Name: AppInit DLLs
Description: The threat actors has used malware to set LoadAppInit_DLLsin the Registry key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windowsin order to establish persistence.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has attempted to use WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence on compromised hosts.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The threat actors replaces the Sticky Keys binary C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exefor persistence.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: The threat actors has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: The threat actors used sticky-keys to obtain unauthenticated, privileged console access.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used COM hijacking for persistence by replacing the legitimate MMDeviceEnumeratorobject with a payload.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used a WMI event filter to invoke a command-line event consumer at system boot time to launch a backdoor with `rundll32.exe`.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence for malware.

Name: Change Default File Association
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by a file type association. When a file is opened, the default program used to open the file (also called the file association or handler) is checked. File association selections are stored in the Windows Registry and can be edited by users, administrators, or programs that have Registry access or by administrators using the built-in assoc utility. Applications can modify the file association for a given file extension to call an arbitrary program when a file with the given extension is opened.

Name: Screensaver
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity. Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension. The Windows screensaver application scrnsave.scr is located in C:\Windows\System32\, and C:\Windows\sysWOW64\ on 64-bit Windows systems, along with screensavers included with base Windows installations.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by a Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) event subscription. WMI can be used to install event filters, providers, consumers, and bindings that execute code when a defined event occurs. Examples of events that may be subscribed to are the wall clock time, user loging, or the computer's uptime.

Name: Unix Shell Configuration Modification
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence through executing malicious commands triggered by a user’s shell. User Unix Shells execute several configuration scripts at different points throughout the session based on events. For example, when a user opens a command-line interface or remotely logs in (such as via SSH) a login shell is initiated. The login shell executes scripts from the system (/etc) and the user’s home directory (~/) to configure the environment. All login shells on a system use /etc/profile when initiated. These configuration scripts run at the permission level of their directory and are often used to set environment variables, create aliases, and customize the user’s environment. When the shell exits or terminates, additional shell scripts are executed to ensure the shell exits appropriately.

Name: Trap
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by an interrupt signal. The trap command allows programs and shells to specify commands that will be executed upon receiving interrupt signals. A common situation is a script allowing for graceful termination and handling of common keyboard interrupts like ctrl+c and ctrl+d.

Name: LC_LOAD_DYLIB Addition
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by the execution of tainted binaries. Mach-O binaries have a series of headers that are used to perform certain operations when a binary is loaded. The LC_LOAD_DYLIB header in a Mach-O binary tells macOS and OS X which dynamic libraries (dylibs) to load during execution time. These can be added ad-hoc to the compiled binary as long as adjustments are made to the rest of the fields and dependencies. There are tools available to perform these changes.

Name: Netsh Helper DLL
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by Netsh Helper DLLs. Netsh.exe (also referred to as Netshell) is a command-line scripting utility used to interact with the network configuration of a system. It contains functionality to add helper DLLs for extending functionality of the utility. The paths to registered netsh.exe helper DLLs are entered into the Windows Registry at HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Netsh.

Name: Accessibility Features
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by accessibility features. Windows contains accessibility features that may be launched with a key combination before a user has logged in (ex: when the user is on the Windows logon screen). An adversary can modify the way these programs are launched to get a command prompt or backdoor without logging in to the system.

Name: AppCert DLLs
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by AppCert DLLs loaded into processes. Dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) that are specified in the AppCertDLLs Registry key under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\ are loaded into every process that calls the ubiquitously used application programming interface (API) functions CreateProcess, CreateProcessAsUser, CreateProcessWithLoginW, CreateProcessWithTokenW, or WinExec.

Name: AppInit DLLs
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by AppInit DLLs loaded into processes. Dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) that are specified in the AppInit_DLLs value in the Registry keys HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows or HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows are loaded by user32.dll into every process that loads user32.dll. In practice this is nearly every program, since user32.dll is a very common library.

Name: Application Shimming
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims. The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time. For example, the application shimming feature allows developers to apply fixes to applications (without rewriting code) that were created for Windows XP so that it will work with Windows 10.

Name: Image File Execution Options Injection
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by Image File Execution Options (IFEO) debuggers. IFEOs enable a developer to attach a debugger to an application. When a process is created, a debugger present in an application’s IFEO will be prepended to the application’s name, effectively launching the new process under the debugger (e.g., C:\dbg\ntsd.exe -g notepad.exe).

Name: PowerShell Profile
Description: Adversaries may gain persistence and elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by PowerShell profiles. A PowerShell profile (profile.ps1) is a script that runs when PowerShell starts and can be used as a logon script to customize user environments.

Name: Emond
Description: Adversaries may gain persistence and elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by the Event Monitor Daemon (emond). Emond is a Launch Daemon that accepts events from various services, runs them through a simple rules engine, and takes action. The emond binary at /sbin/emond will load any rules from the /etc/emond.d/rules/ directory and take action once an explicitly defined event takes place.

Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by hijacked references to Component Object Model (COM) objects. COM is a system within Windows to enable interaction between software components through the operating system. References to various COM objects are stored in the Registry.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: Adversaries may use execution guardrails to constrain execution or actions based on adversary supplied and environment specific conditions that are expected to be present on the target. Guardrails ensure that a payload only executes against an intended target and reduces collateral damage from an adversary’s campaign. Values an adversary can provide about a target system or environment to use as guardrails may include specific network share names, attached physical devices, files, joined Active Directory (AD) domains, and local/external IP addresses.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: The malware dropper component can verify the existence of a single command line parameter and either terminate if it is not found or later use it as a decryption key.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware has the ability to check for the presence of a specific DLL and terminate if it is not found.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware is only delivered to a compromised host if the victim's IP address is on an allow-list.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware checks for specific operating systems on 32-bit machines, Registry keys, and dates for vulnerabilities, and will exit execution if the values are not met.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware can only execute correctly if the word `Platypus` is passed to it on the command line.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware only replaces SolarWinds Orion source code if the MD5 checksums of both the original source code file and backdoored replacement source code match hardcoded values.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: The malware relies on a specific victim hostname to execute and decrypt important strings.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: The malware can use the volume serial number from a target host to generate a unique XOR key for the next stage payload.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware can check for the presence of KM.EkeyAlmaz1C.dll and will halt execution unless it is in the same directory as the rest of the malware's components.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: The malware can use Data Protection API to encrypt its components on the victim’s computer, to evade detection, and to make sure the payload can only be decrypted and loaded on one specific compromised computer.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware can call window.location.pathnameto ensure that embedded files are being executed from the C: drive, and will terminate if they are not.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware can ensure it executes only on intended systems by identifying the victim's volume serial number, hostname, and/or DNS domain.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware can check its current working directory and for the presence of a specific file and terminate if specific values are not found.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware compares file names and paths to a list of excluded names and directory names during encryption.

Name: Execution Guardrails
Description: The malware can terminate itself if specific execution flags are not present.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: The threat actors has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: The threat actors has encrypted payloads using the Data Protection API (DPAPI), which relies on keys tied to specific user accounts on specific machines. the threat actors has also environmentally keyed second stage malware with an RC5 key derived in part from the infected system's volume serial number.

Name: Environmental Keying
Description: Adversaries may environmentally key payloads or other features of malware to evade defenses and constraint execution to a specific target environment. Environmental keying uses cryptography to constrain execution or actions based on adversary supplied environment specific conditions that are expected to be present on the target. Environmental keying is an implementation of Execution Guardrails that utilizes cryptographic techniques for deriving encryption/decryption keys from specific types of values in a given computing environment.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a different protocol than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware may be used to exfiltrate data separate from the main command and control protocol.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can upload collected data and files to an FTP server.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware has the ability to automatically exfiltrate files using the macOS built-in utility /usr/bin/curl.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can exfiltrate data via a DNS tunnel or email, separately from its C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can exfiltrate data over FTP or HTTP, including HTTP via WebDAV.

Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can exfiltrate data over SFTP or HTTPS via WebDAV.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware has used the malware for exfiltration.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware has used a .NET tool named dog.exe to exiltrate information over an e-mail account.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware can exfiltrate credentials over the network via UDP.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can exfiltrate credentials and other information via HTTP POST request, TCP, and DNS.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware has used FTP to exfiltrate reconnaissance data out.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware connects to a predefined domain on port 443 to exfil gathered information.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware can use DNS tunneling for exfiltration of credit card data.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware exfiltrates logs of its execution stored in the /tmpfolder over FTP using the curlcommand.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware exfiltrates collected files over FTP or WebDAV. Exfiltration servers can be separately configured from C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware has used the curl --upload-filecommand to exfiltrate data over HTTP.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware exfiltrates files over FTP.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can send victim data via FTP with credentials hardcoded in the script.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware has exfiltrated its collected data from the infected machine to the C2, sometimes using the MIME protocol.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware uses HTTP to send data to the C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data in HTTP POST headers.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware uses the curl -s -L -ocommand to exfiltrate archived data to a URL.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: Some the malware variants have used South  Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware can be used to create BITS Jobs to upload files from a compromised host.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The malware has routines for exfiltration over SMTP, FTP, and HTTP.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The malware can directly download cloud user data such as OneDrive files.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has exfiltrated victim information using FTP.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.

Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Description: The threat actors has sent locally staged files with collected credentials to C2 servers using cURL.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors malware SierraBravo-Two generates an email message via SMTP containing information about newly infected victims.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has used FTP to exfiltrate collected data.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has sent stolen payment card data to remote servers via HTTP POSTs.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has used FTP to exfiltrate files (separately from the C2 channel).

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors's backdoor can exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.

Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: The threat actors has exfiltrated archives of collected data previously staged on a target's OWA server via HTTPS.

Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exfiltrated collected data over a simple HTTPS request to a password-protected archive staged on a victim's OWA servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exfiltrated victim data via DNS lookups by encoding and prepending it as subdomains to the attacker-controlled domain.

Name: Exfiltration Over Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a symmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.

Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an asymmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.

Name: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an un-encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an existing command and control channel. Stolen data is encoded into the normal communications channel using the same protocol as command and control communications.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has used HTTP to receive stolen information from the infected machine.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can upload collected files and data to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data to the designated C2 server using HTTP POST requests.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has sent data and files from a compromised host to its C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware exfiltrates data stolen from a system over its C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can exfiltrate files from an infected machine to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send collected victim data to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has the ability to exfiltrate data over the C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has used HTTP POSTs to exfil gathered information.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send information about the compromised host and upload data to a hardcoded C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send victim data to an actor-controlled C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can upload files matching a hardcoded set of extensions, such as .doc, .docx, .pdf, and .rar, to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware exfiltrates targeted file extensions in the /Users/folder to the command and control server via unencrypted HTTP. Network packets contain a string with two pieces of information: a file path and the contents of the file in a base64 encoded string.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has the ability to send collected files over its C2.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data over its C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware sends compromised victim information via HTTP.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can exfiltrate collected documents through C2 channels.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send data and files from a compromised host to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has exfiltrated victim data using HTTP POST requests to its C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data over the C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has uploaded collected data and files from a compromised host to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can exfiltrate files from the victim using the downloadcommand.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data over its C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware sent generated reports to the C2 via HTTP POST requests.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has the ability to upload files from the compromised host over a DNS or HTTP C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send collected data in JSON format to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has sent stolen credentials and other data to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can exfiltrate collected data to its C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data to its C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has sent system information to a C2 server via HTTP and HTTPS POST requests.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can transfer files from an infected host to the C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has sent collected data from a compromised host to its C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware has uploaded data and files from a compromised host to its C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send data gathered from the infected machine via HTTP POST request to the C2.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware performs exfiltration over the malware, which is also used for the C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send collected files back over same C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can exfiltrate host and malware information to C2 servers.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can exfiltrate data gathered from the infected system via the established Exchange Web Services API C2 channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send stolen information to C2 nodes including passwords, accounts, and emails.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
Description: The malware can send screenshots files, keylogger data, files, and recorded audio back to the C2 server.

Name: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
