Name: Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium
Description: Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data over a different network medium than the command and control channel. If the command and control network is a wired Internet connection, the exfiltration may occur, for example, over a WiFi connection, modem, cellular data connection, Bluetooth, or another radio frequency (RF) channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over Bluetooth
Description: The malware has a module named BeetleJuice that contains Bluetooth functionality that may be used in different ways, including transmitting encoded information from the infected system over the Bluetooth protocol, acting as a Bluetooth beacon, and identifying other Bluetooth devices in the vicinity.

Name: Exfiltration Over Bluetooth
Description: Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data over Bluetooth rather than the command and control channel. If the command and control network is a wired Internet connection, an adversary may opt to exfiltrate data using a Bluetooth communication channel.

Name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
Description: Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data via a physical medium, such as a removable drive. In certain circumstances, such as an air-gapped network compromise, exfiltration could occur via a physical medium or device introduced by a user. Such media could be an external hard drive, USB drive, cellular phone, MP3 player, or other removable storage and processing device. The physical medium or device could be used as the final exfiltration point or to hop between otherwise disconnected systems.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The malware exfiltrates collected files via removable media from air-gapped victims.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The malware copies staged data to removable drives when they are inserted into the system.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The malware contains a module to move data from airgapped networks to Internet-connected systems by using a removable USB device.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The malware has a feature to copy files from every drive onto a removable drive in a hidden folder.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The malware creates a file named thumb.dd on all USB flash drives connected to the victim. This file contains information about the infected system and activity logs.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The threat actors has exfiltrated data using USB storage devices.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: The threat actors has used a customized the malware variant which could exfiltrate documents from air-gapped networks.

Name: Exfiltration over USB
Description: Adversaries may attempt to exfiltrate data over a USB connected physical device. In certain circumstances, such as an air-gapped network compromise, exfiltration could occur via a USB device introduced by a user. The USB device could be used as the final exfiltration point or to hop between otherwise disconnected systems.

Name: Exfiltration Over Web Service
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service to exfiltrate data rather than their primary command and control channel. Popular Web services acting as an exfiltration mechanism may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to compromise. Firewall rules may also already exist to permit traffic to these services.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Description: The malware can exfiltrate data to cloud storage services such as Dropbox, Google Drive, Amazon S3, and MEGA.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Description: The malware can use a file exfiltration tool to upload specific files to Dropbox.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Description: The malware can send collected data to cloud storage services such as PCloud.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Description: The malware has exfiltrated data to file sharing sites.

Name: Exfiltration Over Web Service
Description: The malware has been used by threat actors to configure servers for data exfiltration.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage

Name: Exfiltration to Code Repository
Description: The malware can use GitHub for data exfiltration.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage

Name: Exfiltration to Code Repository
Description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a code repository rather than over their primary command and control channel. Code repositories are often accessible via an API (ex: https://api.github.com). Access to these APIs are often over HTTPS, which gives the adversary an additional level of protection.

Name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service rather than over their primary command and control channel. Cloud storage services allow for the storage, edit, and retrieval of data from a remote cloud storage server over the Internet.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: Adversaries may attempt to take advantage of a weakness in an Internet-facing computer or program using software, data, or commands in order to cause unintended or unanticipated behavior. The weakness in the system can be a bug, a glitch, or a design vulnerability. These applications are often websites, but can include databases (like SQL), standard services (like SMB or SSH), network device administration and management protocols (like SNMP and Smart Install), and any other applications with Internet accessible open sockets, such as web servers and related services. Depending on the flaw being exploited this may include Exploitation for Defense Evasion.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The malware can be used to automate exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The malware has been dropped through exploitation of CVE-2011-2462, CVE-2013-3163, and CVE-2014-0322.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The malware can gain access by exploiting a Sangfor SSL VPN vulnerability that allows for the placement and delivery of malicious update binaries.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The malware is executed after the attacker gains initial access to a Windows container using a known vulnerability.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The malware is used to automate SQL injection.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has leveraged vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure VPNs to hijack sessions.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has targeted publicly facing web servers, with both automatic and manual vulnerability discovery.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited the Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 and CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 in Exchange Server.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors exploited Apache Struts, Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2017-10271), and Adobe ColdFusion (CVE-2017-3066) vulnerabilities to deliver malware.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited the Microsoft Exchange memory corruption vulnerability (CVE-2020-0688).

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited known vulnerabilities in public-facing infrastructure such as Microsoft Exchange Servers.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited the Log4j utility (CVE-2021-44228), on-premises MS Exchange servers via "ProxyShell" (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523, CVE-2021-31207), and Fortios SSL VPNs (CVE-2018-13379).

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited various vulnerabilities for initial access, including Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has compromised networks by exploiting Internet-facing applications, including vulnerable Microsoft Exchange and SharePoint servers.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065  to compromise on-premises versions of Microsoft Exchange Server, enabling access to email accounts and installation of additional malware.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities for initial compromise.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors exploited a publicly-facing servers including Wildfly/JBoss servers to gain access to the network.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited known vulnerabilities in Fortinet, PulseSecure, and Palo Alto VPN appliances.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has compromised victims by directly exploiting vulnerabilities of public-facing servers, including those associated with Microsoft Exchange and Oracle GlassFish.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has conducted SQL injection attacks, exploited vulnerabilities CVE-2019-19781 and CVE-2020-0688 for Citrix and MS Exchange, and CVE-2018-13379 for Fortinet VPNs.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has gained initial access by exploiting CVE-2019-18935, a vulnerability within Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0, CVE-2017-7269, in order to establish a new HTTP or command and control (C2) server.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2020-5902, an F5 BIP-IP vulnerability, to drop a Linux backdoor. the threat actors has also exploited mis-configured Plesk servers.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has been observed using SQL injection to gain access to systems.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors exploited CVE-2020-10189 against Zoho ManageEngine Desktop Central, and CVE-2019-19781 to compromise Citrix Application Delivery Controllers (ADC) and gateway devices.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has used SQL injection for initial compromise.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2019-19781 for Citrix, CVE-2019-11510 for Pulse Secure VPNs, CVE-2018-13379 for FortiGate VPNs, and CVE-2019-9670 in Zimbra software to gain access.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: The threat actors has used a variety of public exploits, including CVE 2020-0688 and CVE 2020-17144, to gain execution on vulnerable Microsoft Exchange; they have also conducted SQL injection attacks against external websites.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exploited CVE-2020-0688 against the Microsoft Exchange Control Panel to regain access to a network.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: During the attack, threat actors gained initial access by exploiting vulnerabilities in JBoss webservers.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exploited multiple vulnerabilities in externally facing servers.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: During the attack, threat actors used SQL injection exploits against extranet web servers to gain access.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exploited VMWare Horizon Unified Access Gateways that were vulnerable to several Log4Shell vulnerabilities, including CVE-2021-44228, CVE-2021-45046, CVE-2021-45105, and CVE-2021-44832.

Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exploited CVE-2021-44207 in the USAHerds application and CVE-2021-44228 in Log4j, as well as other .NET deserialization, SQL injection, and directory traversal vulnerabilities to gain initial access.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities in client applications to execute code. Vulnerabilities can exist in software due to unsecure coding practices that can lead to unanticipated behavior. Adversaries can take advantage of certain vulnerabilities through targeted exploitation for the purpose of arbitrary code execution. Oftentimes the most valuable exploits to an offensive toolkit are those that can be used to obtain code execution on a remote system because they can be used to gain access to that system. Users will expect to see files related to the applications they commonly used to do work, so they are a useful target for exploit research and development because of their high utility.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware can attempt to exploit known vulnerabilities in Hadoop, Redis, or ActiveMQ when it finds those services running in order to conduct further execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware has relied on CVE-2022-30190 (Follina) for execution during delivery.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware attempts to exploit the following vulnerabilities in order to execute its malicious script: CVE-2012-0874, CVE-2010-1871, CVE-2017-10271, CVE-2018-2894, CVE-2016-3088, JBoss AS 3/4/5/6, and the Hadoop YARN ResourceManager.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware was installed via exploitation of a SolarWinds Orion API authentication bypass vulnerability (CVE-2020-10148).

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware has been embedded in documents exploiting CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2017-8570.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware has installed legitimate but vulnerable Total Video Player software and wdigest.dll library drivers on compromised hosts to exploit stack overflow and input validation vulnerabilities for code execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2018-0802 to deliver the payload.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware has exploited CVE-2011-4369, a vulnerability in the PRC component in Adobe Reader.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware leverages vulnerable versions of Flash to perform execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware can exploit Oracle Java vulnerabilities for execution, including CVE-2011-3544, CVE-2013-2465, CVE-2012-4681, and CVE-2013-2460.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware leverages a known zero-day vulnerability in Adobe Flash to execute the implant into the victims’ machines.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The malware has exploited Office vulnerabilities such as CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2017-8570 for execution during delivery.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited client software vulnerabilities for execution, such as Microsoft Word CVE-2012-0158.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has executed commands through Microsoft security vulnerabilities, including CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0802, and CVE-2012-0158.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has crafted malicious files to exploit CVE-2012-0158 and CVE-2010-3333 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft vulnerabilities, including CVE-2018-0798, CVE-2018-8174, CVE-2018-0802, CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2019-9489 CVE-2020-8468, and CVE-2018-0798 to enable execution of their delivered malicious payloads.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2018-0798 in Equation Editor.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has taken advantage of a known vulnerability in Microsoft Word (CVE 2012-0158) to execute code.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2017-0199 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited vulnerabilities to gain execution including CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2020-0674.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited vulnerabilities in Microsoft PowerPoint via OLE objects (CVE-2014-4114) and Microsoft Word via crafted TIFF images (CVE-2013-3906).

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors uses malicious documents to deliver remote execution exploits as part of. The group has previously exploited CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2012-1856, CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2015-1641.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2017-0199 in Microsoft Word to execute code.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited the Office vulnerability CVE-2017-0199 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited multiple Microsoft Office and .NET vulnerabilities for execution, including CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-8759, and CVE-2017-11882.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2018-4878 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2014-1761, CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2018-0802 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2018-0798 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2017-11882.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has used exploitation of endpoint software, including Microsoft Internet Explorer Adobe Flash vulnerabilities, to gain execution. They have also used zero-day exploits.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has used malicious documents containing exploits for CVE-2021-40444 affecting Microsoft MSHTML.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2011-0611 in Adobe Flash Player to gain execution on a targeted system.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2015-8651 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities, including CVE-2015-1641, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2018-0802.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors had exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft’s Equation Editor (CVE-2017-11882), an Internet Explorer vulnerability (CVE-2018-8174), CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2017-8759.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2014-6352, CVE-2017-0199, and Adobe Flash CVE-2015-5119.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2018-0802, and CVE-2018-0798 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerabilities CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0798, and CVE-2018-0802.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has used exploits for multiple vulnerabilities including CVE-2014-0322, CVE-2012-4792, CVE-2012-1889, and CVE-2013-3893.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2012-0158 and CVE-2010-3333 for execution against targeted systems.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited numerous ActiveX vulnerabilities, including zero-days.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors leveraged the follow exploits in their operations: CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2015-1641, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2019-3396.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has used exploits for Flash Player (CVE-2016-4117, CVE-2018-4878), Word (CVE-2017-0199), Internet Explorer (CVE-2020-1380 and CVE-2020-26411), and Microsoft Edge (CVE-2021-26411) for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has attempted to exploit a known vulnerability in WinRAR (CVE-2018-20250), and attempted to gain remote code execution via a security bypass vulnerability (CVE-2017-11774).

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has used RTF document that includes an exploit to execute malicious code. (CVE-2017-11882)

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited the Adobe Flash Player vulnerability CVE-2015-3113 and Internet Explorer vulnerability CVE-2014-1776.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has used multiple software exploits for common client software, like Microsoft Word, Exchange, and Adobe Reader, to gain code execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited Microsoft Office vulnerability CVE-2017-0262 for execution.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: The threat actors has exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft Office vulnerabilities (CVE-2009-3129, CVE-2012-0158) and vulnerabilities in Adobe Reader and Flash (CVE-2009-4324, CVE-2009-0927, CVE-2011-0609, CVE-2011-0611).

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exploited Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2011-0611, Microsoft Windows Help vulnerability CVE-2010-1885, and several Internet Explorer vulnerabilities, including CVE-2011-1255, CVE-2012-1889, and CVE-2014-0322.

Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Description: During the attack, the threat actors exploited CVE-2017-11882 to execute code on the victim's machine.

Name: Exploitation for Credential Access
Description: Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities in an attempt to collect credentials. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Credentialing and authentication mechanisms may be targeted for exploitation by adversaries as a means to gain access to useful credentials or circumvent the process to gain access to systems. One example of this is MS14-068, which targets Kerberos and can be used to forge Kerberos tickets using domain user permissions. Exploitation for credential access may also result in Privilege Escalation depending on the process targeted or credentials obtained.

Name: Exploitation for Defense Evasion
Description: Adversaries may exploit a system or application vulnerability to bypass security features. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Vulnerabilities may exist in defensive security software that can be used to disable or circumvent them.

Name: Exploitation for Defense Evasion
Description: The threat actors has used CVE-2015-4902 to bypass security features.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities in an attempt to elevate privileges. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Security constructs such as permission levels will often hinder access to information and use of certain techniques, so adversaries will likely need to perform privilege escalation to include use of software exploitation to circumvent those restrictions.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has the ability to leverage local and remote exploits to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has used a zero-day exploit in the ssh launchdaemon to elevate privileges and bypass SIP.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware exploits CVE-2016-4117 to allow an executable to gain escalated privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware used MS10-073 and an undisclosed Task Scheduler vulnerability to escalate privileges on local Windows machines.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has leveraged a vulnerability in Windows containers to perform an Escape to Host.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has a plugin to drop and execute vulnerable Outpost Sandbox or avast! Virtualization drivers in order to gain kernel mode privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware can use CVE-2019-0859 to escalate privileges on a compromised host.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware contains modules for local privilege escalation exploits such as CVE-2016-9192 and CVE-2016-0099.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware can use CVE-2017-15303 to bypass Windows Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) protection and load its driver.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has exploited CVE-2015-1701 and CVE-2015-2387 to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has exploited CVE-2007-5633 vulnerability in the speedfan.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has used the BOtB tool which exploits CVE-2019-5736.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware can exploit vulnerabilities such as MS16-032 and MS16-135.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware attempts to exploit privilege escalation vulnerabilities CVE-2010-0232 or CVE-2010-4398.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware can exploit vulnerabilities such as MS14-058.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The malware has exploited multiple Windows vulnerabilities (CVE-2010-2743, CVE-2010-3338, CVE-2010-4398, CVE-2008-1084) and a .NET Runtime Optimization vulnerability for privilege escalation.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2017-0005 for local privilege escalation.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has used an open-source tool to exploit a known Windows privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2016-0051) on unpatched computers.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited vulnerabilities in the VBoxDrv.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2019-0803 and MS16-032 to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has used CVE-2014-6324 and CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has leveraged a zero-day vulnerability to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited unpatched vulnerabilities on internally accessible servers including JIRA, GitLab, and Confluence for privilege escalation.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited the CVE-2016-0167 local vulnerability.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has used tools to exploit Windows vulnerabilities in order to escalate privileges. The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has used exploits to increase their levels of rights and privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2021-1732 for privilege escalation.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has used a publicly available exploit for CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges on a local system.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2021-36934 to escalate privileges on a compromised host.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: The threat actors has exploited CVE-2014-4076, CVE-2015-2387, CVE-2015-1701, CVE-2017-0263 to escalate privileges.

Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Description: During the attack, the threat actors abused named pipe impersonation for privilege escalation.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: Adversaries may exploit remote services to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a network. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. A common goal for post-compromise exploitation of remote services is for lateral movement to enable access to a remote system.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware uses an exploit in SMBv1 to spread itself to other remote systems on a network.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware utilizes EternalBlue and EternalRomance exploits for lateral movement in the modules wormwinDll, wormDll, mwormDll, nwormDll, tabDll.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware propagates using the MS10-061 Print Spooler and MS08-067 Windows Server Service vulnerabilities.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware can move laterally using worm-like functionality through exploitation of SMB.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware contains a module for exploiting SMB via EternalBlue.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware can use two exploits in SMBv1, EternalBlue and EternalRomance, to spread itself to other remote systems on the network.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware can exploit multiple vulnerabilities including EternalBlue (CVE-2017-0144) and EternalRomance (CVE-2017-0144).

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware can spread within a network via the BlueKeep (CVE-2019-0708) and EternalBlue (CVE-2017-0144) vulnerabilities in RDP and SMB respectively.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware can use MS10-061 to exploit a print spooler vulnerability in a remote system with a shared printer in order to move laterally.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware has a limited number of built-in modules for exploiting remote SMB, JBoss, and Jenkins servers.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware has been seen exploiting SMB via a vulnerability exploit like EternalBlue (MS17-010) to achieve lateral movement and propagation.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware exploited the MS08-067 Windows vulnerability for remote code execution through a crafted RPC request.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The malware used the EternalRomance SMB exploit to spread through victim networks.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used tools to exploit the ZeroLogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has exploited or attempted to exploit Zerologon (CVE-2020-1472) and EternalBlue (MS17-010) vulnerabilities.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used EternalBlue exploits for lateral movement.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has exploited MS17-010 to move laterally to other systems on the network.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has exploited the Microsoft Netlogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has exploited known vulnerabilities in remote services including RDP.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has exploited ZeroLogon (CVE-2020-1472) against vulnerable domain controllers.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used the malware to exploit a domain controller via the ZeroLogon exploit (CVE-2020-1472).

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has exploited a Windows Netlogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472) to obtain access to Windows Active Directory servers.

Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Description: The threat actors exploited a Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability to conduct lateral movement.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network. Remote services such as VPNs, Citrix, and other access mechanisms allow users to connect to internal enterprise network resources from external locations. There are often remote service gateways that manage connections and credential authentication for these services. Services such as Windows Remote Management and VNC can also be used externally.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The malware can establish an SSH connection from a compromised host to a server.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The malware attempts to gain access to the server via SSH.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The malware was executed in an Ubuntu container deployed via an open Docker daemon API.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The malware was executed through an unsecure kubelet that allowed anonymous access to the victim environment.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The malware was executed through an open Docker daemon API port.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has accessed victim networks by using stolen credentials to access the corporate VPN infrastructure.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services. the threat actors has also obtained OWA account credentials during intrusions that it subsequently used to attempt to regain access when evicted from a victim network.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used open-source tools such as Weave Scope to target exposed Docker API ports and gain initial access to victim environments. the threat actors has also targeted exposed kubelets for Kubernetes environments.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used a VPN to persist in the victim environment.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used Dropbear SSH with a hardcoded backdoor password to maintain persistence within the target network. the threat actors has also used VPN tunnels established in legitimate software company infrastructure to gain access to internal networks of that software company's users.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used external remote services such as virtual private networks (VPN) to gain initial access.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has gained access to internet-facing systems and applications, including virtual private network (VPN), remote desktop protocol (RDP), and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) including Citrix.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used RDP to establish persistence.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has gained access through VPNs including with compromised accounts and stolen VPN certificates.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used publicly-accessible RDP and remote management and monitoring (RMM) servers to gain access to victim machines.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used VPN services, including SoftEther VPN, to access and maintain persistence in victim environments.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used legitimate VPN, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used VPNs and Outlook Web Access (OWA) to maintain access to victim networks.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used legitimate credentials to login to an external VPN, Citrix, SSH, and other remote services.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors compromised an online billing/payment service using VPN access between a third-party service provider and the targeted payment service.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used compromised identities to access networks via VPNs and Citrix.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors has used the malware and a variety of commercial VPN services to route brute force authentication attempts.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: The threat actors actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: For the attack, the threat actors used compromised identities to access networks via SSH, VPNs, and other remote access tools.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: During the attack, threat actors used stolen credentials to connect to the victim's network via VPN.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: During the attack, the threat actors enabled WinRM over HTTP/HTTPS as a backup persistence mechanism using the following command: `cscript //nologo "C:\Windows\System32\winrm.vbs" set winrm/config/service@{EnableCompatibilityHttpsListener="true"}`.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: During the attack, threat actors used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.

Name: External Remote Services
Description: During the attack, the threat actors set up remote tunneling using an SSH tool to maintain access to a compromised environment.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: Adversaries may use fallback or alternate communication channels if the primary channel is compromised or inaccessible in order to maintain reliable command and control and to avoid data transfer thresholds.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The C2 server used by the malware provides a port number to the victim to use as a fallback in case the connection closes on the currently used port.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware is usually configured with primary and backup domains for C2 communications.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can communicate over multiple C2 hosts.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can use secondary C2 servers for communication after establishing connectivity and relaying victim information to primary C2 servers.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can go through a list of C2 server IPs and will try to register with each until one responds.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can randomly pick one of five hard-coded IP addresses for C2 communication; if one of the IP fails, it will wait 60 seconds and then try another IP address.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has the ability to generate new C2 domains.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has a hard-coded primary and backup C2 string.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has primarily used port 443 for C2 but can use port 80 as a fallback.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has used a secondary C2 location if the first was unavailable.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can update its configuration to use a different C2 server.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware primarily uses port 80 for C2, but falls back to ports 443 or 8080 if initial communication fails.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has the ability to switch between TCP and HTTP for C2 if one method is not working.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has used HTTP if DNS C2 communications were not functioning.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware uses multiple protocols (HTTPS, HTTP, DNS) for its C2 server as fallback channels if communication with one is unsuccessful.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can switch to an alternate C2 domain when a particular date has been reached.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, the malware will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can use a list of C2 URLs as fallback mechanisms in case one IP or domain gets blocked.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware first attempts to use a Base64-encoded network protocol over a raw TCP socket for C2, and if that method fails, falls back to a secondary HTTP-based protocol to communicate to an alternate C2 server.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware uses Google Search to identify C2 servers if its primary C2 method via Twitter is not working.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has sent data over HTTP if FTP failed, and has also used a fallback server.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can assign hard-coded fallback domains for C2.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can accept multiple URLs for C2 servers.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware tests if it can reach its C2 server by first attempting a direct connection, and if it fails, obtaining proxy settings and sending the connection through a proxy, and finally injecting code into a running browser if the proxy method fails.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has been configured with several servers available for alternate C2 communications.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has multiple C2 channels in place in case one fails.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can use multiple domains and protocols in C2.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has used several C2 servers per targeted organization.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can attempt to find a new C2 server if it receives an error.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has implemented a fallback mechanism to begin using a DGA when the attacker hasn't connected to the infected system for three days.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has two hard-coded domains for C2 servers; if the first does not respond, it will try the second.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware uses a backup communication method with an HTTP beacon.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has used a hardcoded GitHub repository as a fallback channel.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can change its C2 channel once every 360 loops by retrieving a new domain from the actors’ S3 bucket.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can communicate over multiple C2 host and port combinations.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can switch to a new C2 channel if the current one is broken.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can use backup C2 servers if the primary server fails.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has the capability to communicate over a backup channel via plus.google.com.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware has the ability to use an alternative C2 server if the primary server fails.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware malware contains a secondary fallback command and control server that is contacted after the primary command and control server.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can use a second channel for C2 when the primary channel is in upload mode.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The malware can use secondary C2 servers for communication after establishing connectivity and relaying victim information to primary C2 servers.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The threat actors malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The threat actors malware SierraAlfa sends data to one of the hard-coded C2 servers chosen at random, and if the transmission fails, chooses a new C2 server to attempt the transmission again.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The threat actors's Harpy backdoor malware can use DNS as a backup channel for C2 if HTTP fails.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: The threat actors used the Steam community page as a fallback mechanism for C2.

Name: Fallback Channels
Description: During the attack, threat actors used company extranet servers as secondary C2 servers.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information within a file system. Adversaries may use the information from File and Directory Discovery during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can browse the file system.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware gathers information on victim’s drives and has a plugin for document listing.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can browse file systems using a file manager module.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can recursively enumerate files in an operator-provided directory.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can browse file systems.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware has the ability to list the directories on a compromised host.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can be used to find files and directories with native functionality such as dircommands.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can parse collected files to identify specific file extensions.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware has a command to open a file manager and explorer on the system.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can enumerate files on a compromised host.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware searches for specific directories on the victim’s machine.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware searches for files that are 60mb and less and contain the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .exe, .zip, and .rar. the malware also runs the echo %APPDATA%command to list the contents of the directory. the malware can obtain the current execution path as well as perform drive enumeration.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware has the ability to enumerate files and drives.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware has used `mdfind` to enumerate a list of apps known to grant screen sharing permissions.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware contains the readFiles function to return a detailed listing (sometimes recursive) of a specified directory. the malware contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can list all files and their associated attributes, including filename, type, owner, creation time, last access time, last write time, size, and permissions.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can check for the presence of specific files prior to moving to the next phase of execution.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware has the ability to enumerate the users home directory and the path to its own application bundle.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware sets a WH_CBT Windows hook to search for and capture files on the victim.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can locate files based on hardcoded file extensions.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can enumerate files and directories just prior to encryption.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can enumerate directories on a compromise host.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware searches for variety of user files by file extension before encrypting them using RSA and AES, including Office, PDF, image, audio, video, source code, archive/compression format, and key and certificate files.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can enumerate files and directories.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can list directories on a victim.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can detect the victim's file or folder list.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware searches victim drives for files matching certain extensions (“.skr”,“.pkr” or “.key”) or names.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
Description: The malware can search for specific files and list directories.

Name: File and Directory Discovery
