Description: During the attack, the threat actors conducted a file listing discovery against multiple hosts to ensure locker encryption was successful.

Name: File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control lists (ACLs) and access protected files. File and directory permissions are commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the appropriate permissions. File and directory ACL implementations vary by platform, but generally explicitly designate which users or groups can perform which actions (read, write, execute, etc.).

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware uses the chmod +xcommand to grant executable permissions to the malicious file.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware has a command to take ownership of a file and reset the ACL permissions using the takeown.exe /F filepathcommand.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware uses attrib +hand icacls . /grant Everyone:F /T /C /Qto make some of its files hidden and grant all users full access controls.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can launch icacls <path> /grant Everyone:F /T /C /Qto delete every access-based restrictions on files and directories.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can add the executable flag to a downloaded file.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware has the ability to modify file permissions.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware has changed permissions of a second-stage payload to an executable via chmod.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can use the chmodutility to set a file as executable, such as chmod 777or chmod +x.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware has used chmod to modify permissions on key files for use.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can use the command-line utility cacls.exe to change file permissions.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can modify the binary ACL to prevent security tools from running.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware gives all users execute permissions for the application using the command chmod +x /Users/Shared/AppStore.app.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can modify ACL entries to take ownership of files.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware changes the permissions of a payload using the command chmod -R 755.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can use Windows commands such as `fsutil behavior set SymLinkEvaluation R2L:1` to redirect file system access to a different location after gaining access into compromised networks.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware binary can use `chmod` to gain full permissions to targeted files.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The malware can use icacls /resetand takeown /Fto reset a targeted executable's permissions and then take ownership.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The threat actors has used the icacls command to modify access control to backup servers, providing them with full control of all the system folders.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The threat actors has modified the permissions on binaries with chattr.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The threat actors has changed file permissions of files so they could not be modified.

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: The threat actors's macOS backdoor changes the permission of the file it wants to execute to 755.

Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control lists (ACLs) and access protected files. File and directory permissions are commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the appropriate permissions. File and directory ACL implementations vary by platform, but generally explicitly designate which users or groups can perform which actions (read, write, execute, etc.).

Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Description: Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control lists (ACLs) and access protected files. File and directory permissions are commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the appropriate permissions. File and directory ACL implementations vary by platform, but generally explicitly designate which users or groups can perform which actions (read, write, execute, etc.).

Name: Firmware Corruption
Description: Adversaries may overwrite or corrupt the flash memory contents of system BIOS or other firmware in devices attached to a system in order to render them inoperable or unable to boot, thus denying the availability to use the devices and/or the system. Firmware is software that is loaded and executed from non-volatile memory on hardware devices in order to initialize and manage device functionality. These devices could include the motherboard, hard drive, or video cards.

Name: Firmware Corruption
Description: The malware module "Trickboot" can write or erase the UEFI/BIOS firmware of a compromised device.

Name: Firmware Corruption
Description: The malware has used an executable that installs a modified bootloader to prevent normal boot-up.

Name: Forced Authentication
Description: Adversaries may gather credential material by invoking or forcing a user to automatically provide authentication information through a mechanism in which they can intercept.

Name: Forced Authentication
Description: The malware can use protocol handlers to coax the operating system to send NTLMv2 authentication responses to attacker-controlled infrastructure.

Name: Forced Authentication
Description: The threat actors has gathered hashed user credentials over SMB using spearphishing attachments with external resource links and by modifying .LNK file icon resources to collect credentials from virtualized systems.

Name: Forced Authentication
Description: The threat actors used Template Injection to launch an authentication window for users to enter their credentials.

Name: Forge Web Credentials
Description: Adversaries may forge credential materials that can be used to gain access to web applications or Internet services. Web applications and services (hosted in cloud SaaS environments or on-premise servers) often use session cookies, tokens, or other materials to authenticate and authorize user access.

Name: SAML Tokens
Description: The malware can be used to create SAML tokens using the AD Federated Services token signing certificate.

Name: Web Cookies
Description: During the attack, the threat actors bypassed MFA set on OWA accounts by generating a cookie value from a previously stolen secret key.

Name: SAML Tokens
Description: During the attack, the threat actors created tokens using compromised SAML signing certificates.

Name: Web Cookies
Description: Adversaries may forge web cookies that can be used to gain access to web applications or Internet services. Web applications and services (hosted in cloud SaaS environments or on-premise servers) often use session cookies to authenticate and authorize user access.

Name: SAML Tokens
Description: An adversary may forge SAML tokens with any permissions claims and lifetimes if they possess a valid SAML token-signing certificate. The default lifetime of a SAML token is one hour, but the validity period can be specified in the NotOnOrAfter value of the conditions ... element in a token. This value can be changed using the AccessTokenLifetime in a LifetimeTokenPolicy. Forged SAML tokens enable adversaries to authenticate across services that use SAML 2.0 as an SSO (single sign-on) mechanism.

Name: Gather Victim Host Information
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's hosts that can be used during targeting. Information about hosts may include a variety of details, including administrative data (ex: name, assigned IP, functionality, etc.) as well as specifics regarding its configuration (ex: operating system, language, etc.).

Name: Hardware
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host hardware that can be used during targeting. Information about hardware infrastructure may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: card/biometric readers, dedicated encryption hardware, etc.).

Name: Software
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

Name: Firmware
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host firmware that can be used during targeting. Information about host firmware may include a variety of details such as type and versions on specific hosts, which may be used to infer more information about hosts in the environment (ex: configuration, purpose, age/patch level, etc.).

Name: Client Configurations
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's client configurations that can be used during targeting. Information about client configurations may include a variety of details and settings, including operating system/version, virtualization, architecture (ex: 32 or 64 bit), language, and/or time zone.

Name: Gather Victim Identity Information
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's identity that can be used during targeting. Information about identities may include a variety of details, including personal data (ex: employee names, email addresses, etc.) as well as sensitive details such as credentials.

Name: Credentials
Description: Adversaries may gather credentials that can be used during targeting. Account credentials gathered by adversaries may be those directly associated with the target victim organization or attempt to take advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Name: Email Addresses
Description: Adversaries may gather email addresses that can be used during targeting. Even if internal instances exist, organizations may have public-facing email infrastructure and addresses for employees.

Name: Employee Names
Description: Adversaries may gather employee names that can be used during targeting. Employee names be used to derive email addresses as well as to help guide other reconnaissance efforts and/or craft more-believable lures.

Name: Gather Victim Network Information
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's networks that can be used during targeting. Information about networks may include a variety of details, including administrative data (ex: IP ranges, domain names, etc.) as well as specifics regarding its topology and operations.

Name: Domain Properties
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's network domain(s) that can be used during targeting. Information about domains and their properties may include a variety of details, including what domain(s) the victim owns as well as administrative data (ex: name, registrar, etc.) and more directly actionable information such as contacts (email addresses and phone numbers), business addresses, and name servers.

Name: DNS
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's DNS that can be used during targeting. DNS information may include a variety of details, including registered name servers as well as records that outline addressing for a target’s subdomains, mail servers, and other hosts.

Name: Network Trust Dependencies
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's network trust dependencies that can be used during targeting. Information about network trusts may include a variety of details, including second or third-party organizations/domains (ex: managed service providers, contractors, etc.) that have connected (and potentially elevated) network access.

Name: Network Topology
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's network topology that can be used during targeting. Information about network topologies may include a variety of details, including the physical and/or logical arrangement of both external-facing and internal network environments. This information may also include specifics regarding network devices (gateways, routers, etc.) and other infrastructure.

Name: IP Addresses
Description: Adversaries may gather the victim's IP addresses that can be used during targeting. Public IP addresses may be allocated to organizations by block, or a range of sequential addresses. Information about assigned IP addresses may include a variety of details, such as which IP addresses are in use. IP addresses may also enable an adversary to derive other details about a victim, such as organizational size, physical location(s), Internet service provider, and or where/how their publicly-facing infrastructure is hosted.

Name: Network Security Appliances
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's network security appliances that can be used during targeting. Information about network security appliances may include a variety of details, such as the existence and specifics of deployed firewalls, content filters, and proxies/bastion hosts. Adversaries may also target information about victim network-based intrusion detection systems (NIDS) or other appliances related to defensive cybersecurity operations.

Name: Gather Victim Org Information
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's organization that can be used during targeting. Information about an organization may include a variety of details, including the names of divisions/departments, specifics of business operations, as well as the roles and responsibilities of key employees.

Name: Determine Physical Locations
Description: Adversaries may gather the victim's physical location(s) that can be used during targeting. Information about physical locations of a target organization may include a variety of details, including where key resources and infrastructure are housed. Physical locations may also indicate what legal jurisdiction and/or authorities the victim operates within.

Name: Business Relationships
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's business relationships that can be used during targeting. Information about an organization’s business relationships may include a variety of details, including second or third-party organizations/domains (ex: managed service providers, contractors, etc.) that have connected (and potentially elevated) network access. This information may also reveal supply chains and shipment paths for the victim’s hardware and software resources.

Name: Identify Business Tempo
Description: Adversaries may gather information about the victim's business tempo that can be used during targeting. Information about an organization’s business tempo may include a variety of details, including operational hours/days of the week. This information may also reveal times/dates of purchases and shipments of the victim’s hardware and software resources.

Name: Identify Roles
Description: Adversaries may gather information about identities and roles within the victim organization that can be used during targeting. Information about business roles may reveal a variety of targetable details, including identifiable information for key personnel as well as what data/resources they have access to.

Name: Group Policy Discovery
Description: Adversaries may gather information on Group Policy settings to identify paths for privilege escalation, security measures applied within a domain, and to discover patterns in domain objects that can be manipulated or used to blend in the environment. Group Policy allows for centralized management of user and computer settings in Active Directory (AD). Group policy objects (GPOs) are containers for group policy settings made up of files stored within a predicable network path \\SYSVOL\\Policies\.

Name: Group Policy Discovery
Description: The malware includes various modules for enumerating Group Policy.

Name: Group Policy Discovery
Description: The malware has the capability to execute gpresult.

Name: Group Policy Discovery
Description: The malware has the ability to collect local admin information via GPO.

Name: Group Policy Discovery
Description: The threat actors surveys a system upon check-in to discover Group Policy details using the gpresultcommand.

Name: Hardware Additions
Description: Adversaries may introduce computer accessories, networking hardware, or other computing devices into a system or network that can be used as a vector to gain access. Rather than just connecting and distributing payloads via removable storage (i.e. Replication Through Removable Media), more robust hardware additions can be used to introduce new functionalities and/or features into a system that can then be abused.

Name: Hardware Additions
Description: The threat actors used Bash Bunny, Raspberry Pi, netbooks or inexpensive laptops to connect to the company’s local network.

Name: Hide Artifacts
Description: Adversaries may attempt to hide artifacts associated with their behaviors to evade detection. Operating systems may have features to hide various artifacts, such as important system files and administrative task execution, to avoid disrupting user work environments and prevent users from changing files or features on the system. Adversaries may abuse these features to hide artifacts such as files, directories, user accounts, or other system activity to evade detection.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware saves itself with a leading "." so that it's hidden from users by default.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware can be used to read and write alternate data streams.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has created a hidden directory on targeted systems, naming it after the current local time (year, month, and day).

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: Some variants of the malware Trojan have been known to store data in Extended Attributes.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware uses a hidden folder named .xcassetsand .gitto embed itself in Xcode.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware can instruct the OS to execute an application without a dock icon or menu.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware has the ability to save and execute files as an alternate data stream (ADS).

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has copied a random file from the Windows System32 folder to the %APPDATA%location under a different hidden filename.

Name: Hide Artifacts
Description: The malware can masquerade the Process Environment Block on a compromised host to hide it's attempts to elevate privileges through `IFileOperation`.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware uses attrib +hto make some of its files hidden.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware has the ability save and execute files as alternate data streams (ADS).

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware droppers have used COM properties to execute malware in hidden windows.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware hides a copy of itself in the user's ~/Librarydirectory by using a .at the beginning of the file name followed by 9 random characters.

Name: Hide Artifacts
Description: The malware is able to create “hidden” scheduled tasks by deleting the Security Descriptor (`SD`) registry value.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the ability to set file attributes to hidden.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has the ability to hide the console window for its document search module from the user.

Name: Process Argument Spoofing
Description: The malware has the ability to modify its process memory to hide process command-line arguments.

Name: Hidden Users
Description: The malware has modified the Registry to hide created user accounts from the Windows logon screen.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has been created with a hidden attribute to insure it's not visible to the victim.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has the ability to set its window state to hidden.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware can modify file attributes to hide files.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.

Name: Hidden File System
Description: The malware has used a hidden file system to store some of its components.

Name: Run Virtual Instance
Description: The malware has used VirtualBox and a stripped Windows XP virtual machine to run itself. The use of a shared folder specified in the configuration enables the malware to encrypt files on the host operating system, including files on any mapped drives.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has the ability to execute payloads in a hidden window.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware can hide process windows and make web requests invisible to the compromised user. Requests marked as invisible have been sent with user-agent string `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_3) AppleWebKit/537.75.14 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/7.0.3 Safari/7046A194A` though the malware can only be run on Windows systems.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the ability to set file attributes to "hidden" to hide files from the compromised user's view in Windows File Explorer.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has placed its payload in hidden subdirectories.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has added a registry key so future powershell.exe instances are spawned with coordinates for a window position off-screen by default.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware hides many of its backdoor payloads in an alternate data stream (ADS).

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the ability to hide and unhide files.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware can modify the characteristics of folders to hide them from the compromised user.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: If the victim is using PowerShell 3.0 or later, the malware writes its decoded payload to an alternate data stream (ADS) named kernel32.dll that is saved in %PROGRAMDATA%\Windows\.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: Before exfiltration, the malware's backdoor has used hidden files to store logs and outputs from backdoor commands.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware sets the main loader file’s attributes to hidden.

Name: Resource Forking
Description: The malware has used a resource fork to hide a compressed binary file of itself from the terminal, Finder, and potentially evade traditional scanners.

Name: Hide Artifacts
Description: The malware has used the mktemputility to make random and unique filenames for payloads, such as export tmpDir="$(mktemp -d /tmp/XXXXXXXXXXXX)"or mktemp -t Installer.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has executed a .command script from a hidden directory in a mounted DMG.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware can copy itself to and launch itself from hidden folders.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware creates a new hidden directory to store all components' outputs in a dedicated sub-folder for each.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware can hide its console window upon execution to decrease its visibility to a victim.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has hidden its GUI using the ShowWindow() WINAPI call.

Name: Run Virtual Instance
Description: The malware operators have used VirtualBox and a Windows 7 virtual machine to run the ransomware; the virtual machine's configuration file mapped the shared network drives of the target company, presumably so the malware can encrypt files on the shared drives as well as the local machine.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the capability to exfiltrate stolen data to a hidden folder on a removable drive.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware stores itself in ~/Library/.DS_Stores/

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware can modify processes to prevent them from being visible on the desktop.

Name: Run Virtual Instance
Description: The malware has used QEMU and VirtualBox to run a Tiny Core Linux virtual machine, which runs XMRig and makes connections to the C2 server for updates.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has set the attributes of the VirtualBox directory and VBoxVmService parent directory to "hidden".

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the ability to copy itself to a hidden file and directory.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware has loaded an embedded NTFS DXE driver to be able to access and write to NTFS partitions.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware payload is stored in a hidden directory at /Users/Shared/.local/kextd.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has used the command Powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -WindowStyle Hiddento hide its window.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has the ability to conceal its activity through hiding active windows.

Name: Resource Forking
Description: The malware uses a resource fork to present a macOS JPEG or text file icon rather than the executable's icon assigned by the operating system.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware uses -w Hiddento conceal a PowerShell window that downloads a payload.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware can hide the current window from the targeted user via the `ShowWindow` API function.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has used -WindowsStyle Hiddento hide the command window.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware sets its own executable file's attributes to hidden.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has executed legitimate tools in hidden windows.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware can create hidden system directories.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has a dynamic debugging feature to set the file attribute to hidden.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has the ability to hide the window for operations performed on a given file.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has used -WindowStyle hiddento conceal PowerShell windows.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware stores configuration items in alternate data streams (ADSs) if the Registry is not accessible.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware saves itself with a leading "." to make it a hidden file.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has commonly set file and path attributes to hidden.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware can be used to download or copy a file into an alternate data stream.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware can use hidden directories and files to hide malicious executables.

Name: Hide Artifacts
Description: The malware has used `%HiddenReg%` and `%HiddenKey%` as part of its persistence via the Windows registry.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has had its payload named with a dot prefix to make it hidden from view in the Finder application.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The DEADEYE.EMBED variant of the malware can embed its payload in an alternate data stream of a local file.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has executed hidden PowerShell windows.

Name: Hidden File System
Description: The malware has used a portable FAT16 partition image placed in %TEMP% as a hidden file system.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware downloads the following hidden files to evade detection and maintain persistence: /private/tmp/.info.enc, /private/tmp/.info.py, /private/tmp/.server.sh, ~/Library/LaunchAgents/.espl.plist, ~/Library/Containers/.[random string]/[random string].

Name: Process Argument Spoofing
Description: The malware can use spoof arguments in spawned processes that execute beacon commands.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the ability to set its file attributes to hidden.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has created a hidden file in the Startup folder of the current user.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.

Name: Hide Artifacts
Description: The malware uses the mktemputility to make unique file and directory names for payloads, such as TMP_DIR=`mktemp -d -t x.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware has copied itself to the :binalternate data stream of a newly created file.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has the ability to set folders or files to be hidden from the Windows Explorer default view.

Name: Hidden File System
Description: The malware has used unallocated disk space between partitions for a hidden file system that stores components of the Nemesis bootkit.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware uses -windowstyle hiddento conceal a PowerShell window that downloads a payload.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has hidden its console window by using the `ShowWindow` API function.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware can set attributes of log files and directories to HIDDEN, SYSTEM, ARCHIVE, or a combination of those.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware can abuse alternate data streams (ADS) to store content for malicious payloads.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware loads its module with the XSL script parameter vShowset to zero, which opens the application with a hidden window.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has added a leading .to plist filenames, unlisting them from the Finder app and default Terminal directory listings.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The malware has used NTFS to hide files.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The malware has used ProcessWindowStyle.Hiddento hide windows.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The malware has created hidden folders.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors has created a hidden directory under C:\ProgramData\Apple\Updates\and C:\Users\Public\Documents\Flash\.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors can hide legitimate directories and replace them with malicious copies of the same name.

Name: Hidden File System
Description: The threat actors has used a hidden file system that is stored as a file on disk.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors downloaded a file "libprocesshider", which could hide files on the target system.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors executed PowerShell in a hidden window.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors's the malware variant has created a hidden folder on USB drives named RECYCLE.BINto store malicious executables and collected data.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors malware has a function to determine whether the C2 server wishes to execute the newly dropped file in a hidden window.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors has used malware to store malicious binaries in hidden directories on victim's USB drives.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors has used a VBA Macro to set its file attributes to System and Hidden and has named files with a dot prefix to hide them from the Finder application.

Name: Hidden Window

Name: Hidden Window

Description: The threat actors has used -W Hiddento conceal PowerShell windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has used hidconto run batch files in a hidden console window.

Name: Email Hiding Rules
Description: The threat actors has created rules in victims' Microsoft Outlook accounts to automatically delete emails containing words such as “hacked," "phish," and “malware" in a likely attempt to prevent organizations from communicating about their activities.

Name: Hidden File System
Description: The threat actors has used an encrypted virtual file system stored in the Windows Registry.

Name: Hidden Users
Description: The threat actors has modified the Registry to hide created user accounts.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has used -w hiddento conceal PowerShell windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has used -WindowStyle Hiddento conceal PowerShell windows.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has used -w hiddenand -windowstyle hiddento conceal PowerShell windows.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: The threat actors used NTFS alternate data streams to hide their payloads.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal PowerShell windows.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors's macOS backdoor hides the clientID file via a chflags function.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has been known to use -WindowStyle Hiddento conceal PowerShell windows.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal PowerShell windows.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: The threat actors has saved files with hidden file attributes.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: The threat actors used -W Hiddento conceal PowerShell windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.

Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Description: Adversaries may set files and directories to be hidden to evade detection mechanisms. To prevent normal users from accidentally changing special files on a system, most operating systems have the concept of a ‘hidden’ file. These files don’t show up when a user browses the file system with a GUI or when using normal commands on the command line. Users must explicitly ask to show the hidden files either via a series of Graphical User Interface (GUI) prompts or with command line switches (dir /a for Windows and ls –a for Linux and macOS).

Name: Hidden Users
Description: Adversaries may use hidden users to hide the presence of user accounts they create or modify. Administrators may want to hide users when there are many user accounts on a given system or if they want to hide their administrative or other management accounts from other users.

Name: Hidden Window
Description: Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users. In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden. This may be utilized by system administrators to avoid disrupting user work environments when carrying out administrative tasks.

Name: NTFS File Attributes
Description: Adversaries may use NTFS file attributes to hide their malicious data in order to evade detection. Every New Technology File System (NTFS) formatted partition contains a Master File Table (MFT) that maintains a record for every file/directory on the partition. Within MFT entries are file attributes, such as Extended Attributes (EA) and Data [known as Alternate Data Streams (ADSs) when more than one Data attribute is present], that can be used to store arbitrary data (and even complete files).

Name: Hidden File System
Description: Adversaries may use a hidden file system to conceal malicious activity from users and security tools. File systems provide a structure to store and access data from physical storage. Typically, a user engages with a file system through applications that allow them to access files and directories, which are an abstraction from their physical location (ex: disk sector). Standard file systems include FAT, NTFS, ext4, and APFS. File systems can also contain other structures, such as the Volume Boot Record (VBR) and Master File Table (MFT) in NTFS.

Name: Run Virtual Instance
Description: Adversaries may carry out malicious operations using a virtual instance to avoid detection. A wide variety of virtualization technologies exist that allow for the emulation of a computer or computing environment. By running malicious code inside of a virtual instance, adversaries can hide artifacts associated with their behavior from security tools that are unable to monitor activity inside the virtual instance. Additionally, depending on the virtual networking implementation (ex: bridged adapter), network traffic generated by the virtual instance can be difficult to trace back to the compromised host as the IP address and hostname might not match known values.

Name: VBA Stomping
Description: Adversaries may hide malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) payloads embedded within MS Office documents by replacing the VBA source code with benign data.

Name: Email Hiding Rules
Description: Adversaries may use email rules to hide inbound emails in a compromised user's mailbox. Many email clients allow users to create inbox rules for various email functions, including moving emails to other folders, marking emails as read, or deleting emails. Rules may be created or modified within email clients or through external features such as the New-InboxRule or Set-InboxRule PowerShell cmdlets on Windows systems.

Name: Resource Forking
Description: Adversaries may abuse resource forks to hide malicious code or executables to evade detection and bypass security applications. A resource fork provides applications a structured way to store resources such as thumbnail images, menu definitions, icons, dialog boxes, and code. Usage of a resource fork is identifiable when displaying a file’s extended attributes, using ls -l@ or xattr -l commands. Resource forks have been deprecated and replaced with the application bundle structure. Non-localized resources are placed at the top level directory of an application bundle, while localized resources are placed in the /Resources folder.

Name: Process Argument Spoofing
Description: Adversaries may attempt to hide process command-line arguments by overwriting process memory. Process command-line arguments are stored in the process environment block (PEB), a data structure used by Windows to store various information about/used by a process. The PEB includes the process command-line arguments that are referenced when executing the process. When a process is created, defensive tools/sensors that monitor process creations may retrieve the process arguments from the PEB.

Name: Hijack Execution Flow
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the way operating systems run programs. Hijacking execution flow can be for the purposes of persistence, since this hijacked execution may reoccur over time. Adversaries may also use these mechanisms to elevate privileges or evade defenses, such as application control or other restrictions on execution.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can support an HKCMD sideloading start method.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: A the malware variant has used DLL side-loading.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has used DLL side-loading to load malicious payloads.

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Description: The malware adds malicious file paths to the DYLD_FRAMEWORK_PATHand DYLD_LIBRARY_PATHenvironment variables to execute malicious code.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware side loads a malicious file, sspisrv.dll, in part of a spoofed lssas.exe service.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has used DLL side loading to import and load a malicious DLL loader.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware has performed DLL hijacking before execution.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: Variants of the malware achieve persistence by using DLL search order hijacking, usually by copying the DLL file to %SYSTEMROOT%(C:\WINDOWS\ntshrui.dll).

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: During the malware installation process, it drops a copy of the legitimate Microsoft binary igfxtray.exe. The executable contains a side-loading weakness which is used to load a portion of the malware.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can load DLLs through vulnerable legitimate executables.

Name: Hijack Execution Flow
Description: The malware can hijack the cryptbase.dll within migwiz.exe to escalate privileges and bypass UAC controls.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware can hijack outdated Windows application dependencies with malicious versions of its own DLL payload.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can use side-loading to run malicious executables.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can be installed via DLL side-loading.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has the ability to use DLL side-loading for execution.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.

Name: Path Interception by Unquoted Path
Description: The malware contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit unquoted path vulnerabilities.

Name: Path Interception by Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit search order hijacking vulnerabilities.

Name: Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable
Description: The malware contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit path interception opportunities in the PATH environment variable.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit DLL hijacking opportunities in services and processes.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can side-load `Goopdate.dll` into `GoogleUpdate.exe`.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has used DLL side-loading to evade anti-virus.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware has the ability to use DLL search order hijacking for installation on targeted systems.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can use DLL side-loading to execute malicious payloads.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can use DLL side-loading to gain execution.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has side-loaded its malicious DLL file.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware can use DLL hijacking to bypass security controls.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware side loads its communications module as a DLL into the libcurl.dllloader.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can use DLL side-loading to load malicious DLLs.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware can use DLL side-loading to load malicious DLLs into legitimate executables.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has used a legitimate application to sideload a DLL to decrypt, decompress, and run a payload.

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Description: The malware has modified /etc/ld.so.preload to intercept shared library import functions.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware has used DLL Search Order Hijacking to load oci.dllas a persistence mechanism.

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Description: The malware adds itself as a shared object to the LD_PRELOAD environment variable.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The malware has used DLL side-loading.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware abuses the Windows DLL load order by using a legitimate Symantec anti-virus binary, VPDN_LU.exe, to load a malicious DLL that mimics a legitimate Symantec DLL, navlu.dll.

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking

Name: KernelCallbackTable

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking

Name: Path Interception by Unquoted Path

Name: Path Interception by Search Order Hijacking

Name: Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable

Name: Dylib Hijacking
Description: The malware has a dylib hijacker module that generates a malicious dylib given the path to a legitimate dylib of a vulnerable application.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking

Name: Hijack Execution Flow

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking

Name: Services File Permissions Weakness
Description: One variant of the malware locates existing driver services that have been disabled and drops its driver component into one of those service's paths, replacing the legitimate executable. The malware then sets the hijacked service to start automatically to establish persistence.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The malware has exploited the loading of the legitimate Dwrite.dll file by actually loading the gdi library, which then loads the gdiplus library and ultimately loads the local Dwrite dll.

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Side-Loading

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as the malware.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used DLL search order hijacking.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used search order hijacking to run the loader Vcrodat.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has been known to side-load DLLs using a valid version of a Windows Address Book and Windows Defender executable with one of their tools.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors abuses a legitimate and signed Microsoft executable to launch a malicious DLL.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used DLL side-loading, including by using legitimate Kaspersky antivirus variants as well as `rc.exe`, a legitimate Microsoft Resource Compiler.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used DLL side-loading to drop and execute malicious payloads including the hijacking of the legitimate Windows application file rekeywiz.exe.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used a malicious loader DLL file to execute the `credwiz.exe` process and side-load the malicious payload `Duser.dll`.

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has modified /etc/ld.so.preload to hook libc functions in order to hide the installed dropper and mining software in process lists.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used search order hijacking to force TeamViewer to load a malicious DLL.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: A the threat actors .dll that contains the malware is loaded and executed using DLL side-loading.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used DLL side-loading to load malicious DLL's into legitimate executables.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used a legitimately signed executable to execute a malicious payload within a DLL file.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors maintains persistence on victim networks through side-loading dlls to trick legitimate programs into running malware.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used legitimate executables such as `winword.exe` and `igfxem.exe` to side-load their malware.

Name: KernelCallbackTable
Description: The threat actors has abused the KernelCallbackTableto hijack process control flow and execute shellcode.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has replaced `win_fw.dll`, an internal component that is executed during IDA Pro installation, with a malicious DLL to download and execute a payload.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors’s JavaScript file used a legitimate Microsoft Office 2007 package to side-load the OINFO12.OCXdynamic link library.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors used DLL side-loading to covertly load the malware into memory on the victim machine.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used the malware variant, TerraTV, to load a malicious DLL placed in the TeamViewer directory, instead of the original Windows DLL located in a system folder.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has placed a malicious payload in `%WINDIR%\SYSTEM32\oci.dll` so it would be sideloaded by the MSDTC service.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used side loading to place malicious DLLs in memory.

Name: COR_PROFILER
Description: The threat actors has used wmic.exe and Windows Registry modifications to set the COR_PROFILER environment variable to execute a malicious DLL whenever a process loads the .NET CLR.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used DLL side loading by giving DLLs hardcoded names and placing them in searched directories.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has executed DLL search order hijacking.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has used legitimate applications to side-load malicious DLLs.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used DLL search-order hijacking to load `exe`, `dll`, and `dat` files into memory.

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has configured payloads to load via LD_PRELOAD.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors used legitimate executables to perform DLL side-loading of their malware.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: The threat actors has used search order hijacking to execute malicious payloads, such as Winnti RAT.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: The threat actors launched an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant using a legitimate executable that loaded the malicious DLL.

Name: Services Registry Permissions Weakness
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used a batch file that modified the COMSysApp service to load a malicious ipnet.dll payload and to load a DLL into the `svchost.exe` process.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used the legitimate Windows services `IKEEXT` and `PrintNotify` to side-load malicious DLLs.

Name: Hijack Execution Flow
Description: During the attack, the threat actors established persistence by loading malicious libraries via modifications to the Import Address Table (IAT) within legitimate Microsoft binaries.

Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the search order used to load DLLs. Windows systems use a common method to look for required DLLs to load into a program. Hijacking DLL loads may be for the purpose of establishing persistence as well as elevating privileges and/or evading restrictions on file execution.

Name: DLL Side-Loading
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by side-loading DLLs. Similar to DLL Search Order Hijacking, side-loading involves hijacking which DLL a program loads. But rather than just planting the DLL within the search order of a program then waiting for the victim application to be invoked, adversaries may directly side-load their payloads by planting then invoking a legitimate application that executes their payload(s).

Name: Dylib Hijacking
Description: Adversaries may execute their own payloads by placing a malicious dynamic library (dylib) with an expected name in a path a victim application searches at runtime. The dynamic loader will try to find the dylibs based on the sequential order of the search paths. Paths to dylibs may be prefixed with @rpath, which allows developers to use relative paths to specify an array of search paths used at runtime based on the location of the executable. Additionally, if weak linking is used, such as the LC_LOAD_WEAK_DYLIB function, an application will still execute even if an expected dylib is not present. Weak linking enables developers to run an application on multiple macOS versions as new APIs are added.

Name: Executable Installer File Permissions Weakness
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the binaries used by an installer. These processes may automatically execute specific binaries as part of their functionality or to perform other actions. If the permissions on the file system directory containing a target binary, or permissions on the binary itself, are improperly set, then the target binary may be overwritten with another binary using user-level permissions and executed by the original process. If the original process and thread are running under a higher permissions level, then the replaced binary will also execute under higher-level permissions, which could include SYSTEM.

Name: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking environment variables the dynamic linker uses to load shared libraries. During the execution preparation phase of a program, the dynamic linker loads specified absolute paths of shared libraries from environment variables and files, such as LD_PRELOAD on Linux or DYLD_INSERT_LIBRARIES on macOS. Libraries specified in environment variables are loaded first, taking precedence over system libraries with the same function name. These variables are often used by developers to debug binaries without needing to recompile, deconflict mapped symbols, and implement custom functions without changing the original library.

Name: Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking environment variables used to load libraries. Adversaries may place a program in an earlier entry in the list of directories stored in the PATH environment variable, which Windows will then execute when it searches sequentially through that PATH listing in search of the binary that was called from a script or the command line.

Name: Path Interception by Search Order Hijacking
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the search order used to load other programs. Because some programs do not call other programs using the full path, adversaries may place their own file in the directory where the calling program is located, causing the operating system to launch their malicious software at the request of the calling program.

Name: Path Interception by Unquoted Path
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking vulnerable file path references. Adversaries can take advantage of paths that lack surrounding quotations by placing an executable in a higher level directory within the path, so that Windows will choose the adversary's executable to launch.

Name: Services File Permissions Weakness
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the binaries used by services. Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions of Windows services to replace the binary that is executed upon service start. These service processes may automatically execute specific binaries as part of their functionality or to perform other actions. If the permissions on the file system directory containing a target binary, or permissions on the binary itself are improperly set, then the target binary may be overwritten with another binary using user-level permissions and executed by the original process. If the original process and thread are running under a higher permissions level, then the replaced binary will also execute under higher-level permissions, which could include SYSTEM.

Name: Services Registry Permissions Weakness
Description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services. Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for Registry keys related to services to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code when a service starts. Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services. The information stored under a service's Registry keys can be manipulated to modify a service's execution parameters through tools such as the service controller, sc.exe, PowerShell, or Reg. Access to Registry keys is controlled through access control lists and user permissions.

Name: COR_PROFILER
Description: Adversaries may leverage the COR_PROFILER environment variable to hijack the execution flow of programs that load the .NET CLR. The COR_PROFILER is a .NET Framework feature which allows developers to specify an unmanaged (or external of .NET) profiling DLL to be loaded into each .NET process that loads the Common Language Runtime (CLR). These profilers are designed to monitor, troubleshoot, and debug managed code executed by the .NET CLR.

Name: KernelCallbackTable
Description: Adversaries may abuse the KernelCallbackTable of a process to hijack its execution flow in order to run their own payloads. The KernelCallbackTable can be found in the Process Environment Block (PEB) and is initialized to an array of graphic functions available to a GUI process once user32.dll is loaded.

Name: Impair Defenses
Description: Adversaries may maliciously modify components of a victim environment in order to hinder or disable defensive mechanisms. This not only involves impairing preventative defenses, such as firewalls and anti-virus, but also detection capabilities that defenders can use to audit activity and identify malicious behavior. This may also span both native defenses as well as supplemental capabilities installed by users and administrators.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware has modified the Windows firewall to allow itself to communicate through the firewall.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware can be used to disable local firewall settings.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has searched for the Activity Monitor process in the System Events process list and kills the process if running. the malware also searches the operating system's `install.log` for apps matching its hardcoded list, killing all matching process names.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can kill AV products' processes.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware can disable the firewall by modifying the registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\SharedAccess\Parameters\FirewallPolicy\StandardProfile.

Name: Indicator Blocking
Description: The malware has suppressed all error reporting by calling `SetErrorMode` with 0x8007 as a parameter.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can download and execute AdvancedRun.exe to disable the Windows Defender Theat Protection service and set an exclusion path for the C:\ drive.

Name: Disable Windows Event Logging
Description: The malware can be used to disable specific event logs on the system.

Name: Indicator Blocking
Description: The malware can hook the ZwOpenProcessand GetExtendedTcpTableAPIs called by the process of a security product to hide PIDs and TCP records from detection.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can disarm Windows Defender during the UAC process to evade detection.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has functionality to disable security tools, including Kaspersky, BitDefender, and MalwareBytes.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can disable Windows Defender.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can disable Avira anti-virus.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware uses the function kill_unwantedto obtain a list of running processes and kills each process matching a list of security related processes.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware can open the Windows Firewall on the victim’s machine to allow incoming connections.

Name: Impair Defenses
Description: The malware reduces the integrity level of objects to allow write actions.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can add directories used by the malware to the Windows Defender exclusions list to prevent detection.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware identifies and kills anti-malware processes.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has the ability to set SELinux to permissive mode.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware attempted to disable software security services following checks against a FNV-1a + XOR hashed hardcoded blocklist.

Name: Impair Command History Logging
Description: The malware can bypass ScriptBlock logging to execute unmanaged PowerShell code from memory.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware's `amsiPatch.py` module can disable Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) functions.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has stopped services related to anti-virus.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware kills antimalware running process.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware will search for Windows services that are associated with antivirus software on the system and kill the process.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware can add or remove applications or ports on the Windows firewall or disable it entirely.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has attempted to terminate/stop processes and services associated with endpoint security products.

Name: Safe Mode Boot
Description: The malware can force a reboot in safe mode with networking.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can connect to and disable the Symantec server on the victim's network.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has the ability to modify the Registry to add its binaries to the Windows Defender exclusion list.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has the capability to stop antivirus services and disable Windows Defender.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware has modified firewall rules to allow incoming SMB, NetBIOS, and RPC connections using `netsh.exe` on remote machines.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware kills security tools like Wireshark that are running.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can disable Microsoft Office Protected View by changing Registry keys.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can detect and terminate active security software-related processes on infected systems.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can modify the victim's anti-virus.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware can modify the victim's firewall.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can change Internet Explorer settings to reduce warnings about malware activity.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can attempt to uninstall Kaspersky Antivirus or remove the Kaspersky license; it can also add all files and folders related to the attack to the Windows Defender exclusion list.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has a function to kill processes associated with defenses and can prevent certain processes from launching.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware was used to kill endpoint security processes.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has disabled dynamic analysis and other security tools including IDA debugger, x32dbg, and OllyDbg. It has also disabled Windows Defender's Real-Time Monitoring feature and attempted to disable endpoint protection services.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware installation has been immediately preceded by a "task kill" command in order to disable anti-virus.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware has the ability to change firewall settings to allow a plug-in to be downloaded.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware will attempt to delete or disable all Registry keys and scheduled tasks related to Microsoft Security Defender and Security Essentials.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can lower security settings by changing Registry keys.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware has a command to disable routing and the Firewall on the victim’s machine.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has a feature to disable Windows Task Manager.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware has modified DNS resolvers to evade DNS monitoring tools.

Name: Indicator Blocking
Description: The malware has the ability to set the `HKLM:\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\CrashControl\CrashDumpEnabled` Registry key to `0` in order to disable crash dumps.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware has modified the firewall using the malware.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware kills anti-virus found on the victim.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware opens the Windows Firewall to modify incoming connections.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware kills and disables services for Windows Security Center, and Windows Defender.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: The malware kills and disables services for Windows Firewall.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: The malware can hook APIs, kill processes, break file system paths, and change ACLs to prevent security tools from running.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall

Name: Disable Windows Event Logging
Description: During the attack, the threat actors, used `AUDITPOL` to prevent the collection of audit logs.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: During the attack, threat actors used PowerShell to add and delete rules in the Windows firewall.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: During the attack, threat actors disabled anti-virus and anti-spyware tools in some instances on the victim’s machines. The actors also disabled proxy settings to allow direct communication from victims to the Internet.

Name: Disable Windows Event Logging
Description: During the attack, the threat actors disabled event logging on compromised systems.

Name: Disable or Modify Tools
Description: Adversaries may modify and/or disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their malware/tools and activities. This may take the many forms, such as killing security software processes or services, modifying / deleting Registry keys or configuration files so that tools do not operate properly, or other methods to interfere with security tools scanning or reporting information.

Name: Disable Windows Event Logging
Description: Adversaries may disable Windows event logging to limit data that can be leveraged for detections and audits. Windows event logs record user and system activity such as login attempts, process creation, and much more. This data is used by security tools and analysts to generate detections.

Name: Impair Command History Logging
Description: Adversaries may impair command history logging to hide commands they run on a compromised system. Various command interpreters keep track of the commands users type in their terminal so that users can retrace what they've done.

Name: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Description: Adversaries may disable or modify system firewalls in order to bypass controls limiting network usage. Changes could be disabling the entire mechanism as well as adding, deleting, or modifying particular rules. This can be done numerous ways depending on the operating system, including via command-line, editing Windows Registry keys, and Windows Control Panel.

Name: Indicator Blocking
Description: An adversary may attempt to block indicators or events typically captured by sensors from being gathered and analyzed. This could include maliciously redirecting or even disabling host-based sensors, such as Event Tracing for Windows (ETW), by tampering settings that control the collection and flow of event telemetry. These settings may be stored on the system in configuration files and/or in the Registry as well as being accessible via administrative utilities such as PowerShell or Windows Management Instrumentation.

Name: Disable or Modify Cloud Firewall
Description: Adversaries may disable or modify a firewall within a cloud environment to bypass controls that limit access to cloud resources. Cloud firewalls are separate from system firewalls that are described in Disable or Modify System Firewall.

Name: Disable Cloud Logs
Description: An adversary may disable cloud logging capabilities and integrations to limit what data is collected on their activities and avoid detection.

Name: Safe Mode Boot
Description: Adversaries may abuse Windows safe mode to disable endpoint defenses. Safe mode starts up the Windows operating system with a limited set of drivers and services. Third-party security software such as endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools may not start after booting Windows in safe mode. There are two versions of safe mode: Safe Mode and Safe Mode with Networking. It is possible to start additional services after a safe mode boot.

Name: Downgrade Attack
Description: Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls such as logging. For example, PowerShell versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL) which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to Impair Defenses while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.

Name: Implant Internal Image
Description: Adversaries may implant cloud or container images with malicious code to establish persistence after gaining access to an environment. Amazon Web Services (AWS) Amazon Machine Images (AMIs), Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Images, and Azure Images as well as popular container runtimes such as Docker can be implanted or backdoored. Unlike Upload Malware, this technique focuses on adversaries implanting an image in a registry within a victim’s environment. Depending on how the infrastructure is provisioned, this could provide persistent access if the infrastructure provisioning tool is instructed to always use the latest image.

Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Description: Adversaries may delete or modify artifacts generated on a host system to remove evidence of their presence or hinder defenses. Various artifacts may be created by an adversary or something that can be attributed to an adversary’s actions. Typically these artifacts are used as defensive indicators related to monitored events, such as strings from downloaded files, logs that are generated from user actions, and other data analyzed by defenders. Location, format, and type of artifact (such as command or login history) are often specific to each platform.

Name: Clear Windows Event Logs

Name: File Deletion
Description: During the attack, the threat actors removed all previously delivered files from a compromised computer.

Name: Clear Windows Event Logs
Description: Adversaries may clear Windows Event Logs to hide the activity of an intrusion. Windows Event Logs are a record of a computer's alerts and notifications. There are three system-defined sources of events: System, Application, and Security, with five event types: Error, Warning, Information, Success Audit, and Failure Audit.

Name: Clear Linux or Mac System Logs
Description: Adversaries may clear system logs to hide evidence of an intrusion. macOS and Linux both keep track of system or user-initiated actions via system logs. The majority of native system logging is stored under the /var/log/ directory. Subfolders in this directory categorize logs by their related functions, such as:

Name: Clear Command History
Description: In addition to clearing system logs, an adversary may clear the command history of a compromised account to conceal the actions undertaken during an intrusion. Various command interpreters keep track of the commands users type in their terminal so that users can retrace what they've done.

Name: File Deletion
Description: Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity. Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary (ex: Ingress Tool Transfer) may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how. Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint.

Name: Network Share Connection Removal
Description: Adversaries may remove share connections that are no longer useful in order to clean up traces of their operation. Windows shared drive and SMB/Windows Admin Shares connections can be removed when no longer needed. Net is an example utility that can be used to remove network share connections with the net use \system\share /delete command.

Name: Timestomp
Description: Adversaries may modify file time attributes to hide new or changes to existing files. Timestomping is a technique that modifies the timestamps of a file (the modify, access, create, and change times), often to mimic files that are in the same folder. This is done, for example, on files that have been modified or created by the adversary so that they do not appear conspicuous to forensic investigators or file analysis tools.

Name: Indirect Command Execution
Description: Adversaries may abuse utilities that allow for command execution to bypass security restrictions that limit the use of command-line interpreters. Various Windows utilities may be used to execute commands, possibly without invoking cmd. For example, Forfiles, the Program Compatibility Assistant (pcalua.exe), components of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), as well as other utilities may invoke the execution of programs and commands from a Command and Scripting Interpreter, Run window, or via scripts.

Name: Indirect Command Execution
Description: The malware uses the malware utility to execute commands on the system.

Name: Indirect Command Execution
Description: The malware can be used to subvert controls and possibly conceal command execution by not directly invoking the malware.

Name: Indirect Command Execution

Name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment. Tools or files may be copied from an external adversary-controlled system to the victim network through the command and control channel or through alternate protocols such as ftp. Once present, adversaries may also transfer/spread tools between victim devices within a compromised environment (i.e. Lateral Tool Transfer).

Name: Inhibit System Recovery
Description: Adversaries may delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off services designed to aid in the recovery of a corrupted system to prevent recovery. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Name: Input Capture
Description: Adversaries may use methods of capturing user input to obtain credentials or collect information. During normal system usage, users often provide credentials to various different locations, such as login pages/portals or system dialog boxes. Input capture mechanisms may be transparent to the user (e.g. Credential API Hooking) or rely on deceiving the user into providing input into what they believe to be a genuine service (e.g. Web Portal Capture).
