Name: System Time Discovery
Description: As part of the data reconnaissance phase, the malware grabs the system time to send back to the control server.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware has commands to get the time the machine was built, the time, and the time zone.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can send time zone information from a compromised host to C2.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware checks to see if the system is configured with "Daylight" time and checks for a specific region to be set for the timezone.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can obtain the date and time of the compromised system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The net timecommand can be used in the malware to determine the local or remote system time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can collect the current timestamp of the victim's machine.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware obtains the victim's current time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware uses JavaScript to get the system time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can obtain the current tick count of an infected computer.

Name: System Time Discovery

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware has been observed collecting system time from victim machines.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can collect the date and time from a compromised host.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can obtain the date and time of a system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can determine the time on the victim machine via IPinfo.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can check the current date-time value of the compromised system, comparing it to the hardcoded execution trigger and can send the current timestamp to the C2 server.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve the date and time of the system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can check system time to help determine when changes were made to specified files.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware gathers the time zone information from the victim’s machine.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware has used the API calls NtQuerySystemTime, GetSystemTimeAsFileTime, and GetTickCount to gather time metrics as part of its checks to see if the malware is running in a sandbox.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware uses the net timecommand  to get the system time from the machine and collect the current date and time zone information.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware contains functionality to query the local/system time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can collect the time zone information from the system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can use the `GetTickCount` and `GetSystemTimeAsFileTime` API calls to inspect system time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can compare the current time on an infected host with a configuration value to determine when to start the encryption process.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware has the ability to determine the date and time on a compromised host.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware uses the current UTC victim system date for domain generation and connects to time servers to determine the current date.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware has checked the victim system's date and time to perform tasks during business hours (9 to 5, Monday to Friday).

Description: The malware can determine the current time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware uses the command net time \\127.0.0.1to get information the system’s time.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The malware can collect the current time zone information from the victim’s machine.

Description: The malware can check the system time set on the infected host.

Description: The malware has the ability to determine local time on a compromised host.

Description: The malware has checked the system time before and after encryption.

Description: The malware can pull a timestamp from the victim's machine.

Description: The malware can collect the timestamp from the victim’s machine.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The threat actors has used a tool to capture the time on a compromised host in order to register it with C2.

Description: The threat actors surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net timecommand.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The threat actors has checked the current date on the victim system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: A Destover-like implant used by the threat actors can obtain the current system time and send it to the C2 server.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The threat actors has used time /tand net time \\ip/hostnamefor system time discovery.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: The threat actors has used net timeto check the local time on a target system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: During the attack, threat actors used the `time` command to retrieve the current time of a compromised system.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used the `net time` command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.

Name: System Time Discovery
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used the command `net view /all time` to gather the local time of a compromised network.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: Adversaries may deliver payloads to remote systems by adding content to shared storage locations, such as network drives or internal code repositories. Content stored on network drives or in other shared locations may be tainted by adding malicious programs, scripts, or exploit code to otherwise valid files. Once a user opens the shared tainted content, the malicious portion can be executed to run the adversary's code on a remote system. Adversaries may use tainted shared content to move laterally.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware has copied itself to and infected files in network drives for propagation.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware infects remote servers via network shares and by infecting WinCC database views with malicious code.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware can spread itself by infecting other portable executable files on networks shared drives.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware copies itself into the public folder of Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices and infects new victims who open the file.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware can replace legitimate software or documents in the compromised network with their trojanized versions, in an attempt to propagate itself within the network.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware has functionality to copy itself to network shares.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The malware can spread itself by infecting other remote machines via network shared drives.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The threat actors has injected malicious macros into all Word and Excel documents on mapped network drives.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The threat actors used a virus that propagates by infecting executables stored on shared drives.

Name: Taint Shared Content
Description: The threat actors has placed malware on file shares and given it the same name as legitimate documents on the share.

Name: Template Injection
Description: Adversaries may create or modify references in user document templates to conceal malicious code or force authentication attempts. For example, Microsoft’s Office Open XML (OOXML) specification defines an XML-based format for Office documents (.docx, xlsx, .pptx) to replace older binary formats (.doc, .xls, .ppt). OOXML files are packed together ZIP archives compromised of various XML files, referred to as parts, containing properties that collectively define how a document is rendered.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The malware has been install via template injection through a malicious DLL embedded within a template RTF in a Word document.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The malware changed the template target of the settings.xml file embedded in the Word document and populated that field with the downloaded URL of the next payload.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors delivered malicious documents with the XLSX extension, typically used by OpenXML documents, but the file itself was actually an OLE (XLS) document.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors has used decoy documents to load malicious remote payloads via HTTP.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors has used DOCX files to download malicious DOT document templates and has used RTF template injection to download malicious payloads. the threat actors can also inject malicious macros or remote templates into documents already present on compromised systems.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate Forced Authentication.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors used an open-source tool, Phishery, to inject malicious remote template URLs into Microsoft Word documents and then sent them to victims to enable Forced Authentication.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors has used a weaponized Microsoft Word document with an embedded RTF exploit.

Name: Template Injection
Description: The threat actors used weaponized Microsoft Word documents abusing the remote template function to retrieve a malicious macro.

Name: Template Injection
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used DOCX files to retrieve a malicious document template/DOTM file.

Name: Template Injection
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used trojanized documents that retrieved remote templates from an adversary-controlled website.

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: Adversaries may use traffic signaling to hide open ports or other malicious functionality used for persistence or command and control. Traffic signaling involves the use of a magic value or sequence that must be sent to a system to trigger a special response, such as opening a closed port or executing a malicious task. This may take the form of sending a series of packets with certain characteristics before a port will be opened that the adversary can use for command and control. Usually this series of packets consists of attempted connections to a predefined sequence of closed ports (i.e. Port Knocking), but can involve unusual flags, specific strings, or other unique characteristics. After the sequence is completed, opening a port may be accomplished by the host-based firewall, but could also be implemented by custom software.

Name: Port Knocking
Description: The malware has authenticated itself to a different implant, Cryshell, through a port knocking and handshake procedure.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware has used a passive listener, capable of identifying a specific magic value before executing tasking, as a secondary command and control (C2) mechanism.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware can be sent instructions via special packets to change its functionality. Code for new functionality can be included in these messages.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware has used Wake-on-Lan to power on turned off systems for lateral movement.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware will connect to C2 only after sniffing a "magic packet" value in TCP or UDP packets matching specific conditions.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Socket Filters
Description: The malware installs a `TCP` and `UDP` filter on the `eth0` interface.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware can identify if incoming HTTP traffic contains a token and if so it will intercept the traffic and process the received command.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Port Knocking
Description: The malware can use port-knocking to authenticate itself to another implant called Cryshell to establish an indirect connection to the C2 server.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware is triggered by an incoming TCP connection to a legitimate service from a specific source port.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Traffic Signaling
Description: The malware provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Port Knocking
Description: The threat actors has used a script that configures the knockd service and firewall to only accept C2 connections from systems that use a specified sequence of knock ports.
tactics: Command and Control, Defense Evasion, Persistence

Name: Port Knocking
Description: Adversaries may use port knocking to hide open ports used for persistence or command and control. To enable a port, an adversary sends a series of attempted connections to a predefined sequence of closed ports. After the sequence is completed, opening a port is often accomplished by the host based firewall, but could also be implemented by custom software.

Name: Transfer Data to Cloud Account
Description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data by transferring the data, including backups of cloud environments, to another cloud account they control on the same service to avoid typical file transfers/downloads and network-based exfiltration detection.

Name: Trusted Developer Utilities Proxy Execution
Description: Adversaries may take advantage of trusted developer utilities to proxy execution of malicious payloads. There are many utilities used for software development related tasks that can be used to execute code in various forms to assist in development, debugging, and reverse engineering. These utilities may often be signed with legitimate certificates that allow them to execute on a system and proxy execution of malicious code through a trusted process that effectively bypasses application control solutions.

Name: MSBuild
Description: A version of the malware loads as shellcode within a .NET Framework project using msbuild.exe, presumably to bypass application control techniques.

Name: MSBuild
Description: The malware can use built-in modules to abuse trusted utilities like MSBuild.exe.

Name: MSBuild
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used MSbuild to execute an actor-created file.

Name: MSBuild
Description: Adversaries may use MSBuild to proxy execution of code through a trusted Windows utility. MSBuild.exe (Microsoft Build Engine) is a software build platform used by Visual Studio. It handles XML formatted project files that define requirements for loading and building various platforms and configurations.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: Adversaries may breach or otherwise leverage organizations who have access to intended victims. Access through trusted third party relationship exploits an existing connection that may not be protected or receives less scrutiny than standard mechanisms of gaining access to a network.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has compromised third party service providers to gain access to victim's environments.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has used dedicated network connections from one victim organization to gain unauthorized access to a separate organization.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has used compromised credentials from an IT company to target downstream customers including a law firm and aviation company.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has accessed internet-facing identity providers such as Azure Active Directory and Okta to target specific organizations.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has breached Managed Service Providers (MSP's) to deliver malware to MSP customers.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: The threat actors has compromised IT, cloud services, and managed services providers to gain broad access to multiple customers for subsequent operations.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: Once the threat actors gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.

Name: Trusted Relationship
Description: During the attack, the threat actors gained access through compromised accounts at cloud solution partners, and used compromised certificates issued by Mimecast to authenticate to Mimecast customer systems.

Name: Unsecured Credentials
Description: Adversaries may search compromised systems to find and obtain insecurely stored credentials. These credentials can be stored and/or misplaced in many locations on a system, including plaintext files (e.g. Bash History), operating system or application-specific repositories (e.g. Credentials in Registry), or other specialized files/artifacts (e.g. Private Keys).

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: If an initial connectivity check fails, the malware attempts to extract proxy details and credentials from Windows Protected Storage and from the IE Credentials Store. This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware can steal keys for VPNs and cryptocurrency wallets.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can capture passwords from common chat applications such as MSN Messenger, AOL, Instant Messenger, and and Google Talk.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware is capable of accessing locally stored passwords on victims.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The malware can use the clientgrabber module to steal e-mail credentials from the Registry.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The malware has retrieved PuTTY credentials by querying the Software\SimonTatham\Putty\Sessionsregistry key

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can obtain passwords stored in files from several applications such as Outlook, Filezilla, OpenSSH, OpenVPN and WinSCP. Additionally, it searches for the ".vnc.lnk" affix to steal VNC credentials.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials.

Name: Group Policy Preferences
Description: The malware has a module that can extract cached GPP passwords.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The malware may be used to find credentials in the Windows Registry.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can obtain passwords from FTP clients.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware has extracted credentials from the password database before encrypting the files.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.

Name: Group Policy Preferences
Description: The malware contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can harvest credentials from Group Policy Preferences.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The malware has several modules that search the Windows Registry for stored credentials: Get-UnattendedInstallFile, Get-Webconfig, Get-ApplicationHost, Get-SiteListPassword, Get-CachedGPPPassword, and Get-RegistryAutoLogon.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware contains modules for searching for passwords in local and remote files.

Name: Container API
Description: The malware can query the Kubernetes API for secrets.

Name: Cloud Instance Metadata API
Description: The malware can query the query AWS and GCP metadata APIs for secrets.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware's CRYPTO::Extractmodule can extract keys by interacting with Windows cryptographic application programming interface (API) functions.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware can collect a Chrome encryption key used to protect browser cookies.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware has scanned and looked for cryptographic keys and certificate file extensions.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can obtain credentials from chats, databases, mail, and WiFi.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware has searched for private keys.

Name: Bash History
Description: The malware has searched bash_historyfor credentials.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The malware can harvest credentials from local and remote host registries.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware has searched for private keys in .ssh.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware has searched for SSH keys, Docker credentials, and Kubernetes service tokens.

Name: Cloud Instance Metadata API
Description: The malware has queried the Cloud Instance Metadata API for cloud credentials.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware can retrieve token signing certificates and token decryption certificates from a compromised AD FS server.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware can use modules like Invoke-SessionGopherto extract private key and session information.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can use various modules to search for files containing passwords.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware has been observed leveraging a module that retrieves passwords stored on a system for the current logged-on user.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware has intercepted unencrypted private keys as well as private key pass-phrases.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware has used a plug-in to gather credentials stored in files on the host by various software programs, including The Bat! email client, Outlook, and Windows Credential Store.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can steal credentials in files belonging to common software such as Skype, Telegram, and Steam.

Name: Unsecured Credentials
Description: The malware uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The malware has the ability to extract credentials from the Registry.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware has the ability to extract credentials from configuration or support files.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The malware can gather encryption keys from Azure AD services such as ADSync and Active Directory Federated Services servers.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The malware can gather unsecured credentials for Azure AD services, such as Azure AD Connect, from a local machine.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The threat actors has searched for unsecured SSH keys.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has searched for unsecured AWS credentials and Docker API credentials.

Name: Cloud Instance Metadata API
Description: The threat actors has queried the AWS instance metadata service for credentials.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has used malware to gather credentials from FTP clients and Outlook.

Name: Private Keys
Description: The threat actors has used SSH private keys on the infected machine to spread its coinminer throughout a network.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has used credential dumping tools such as the malware to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has run a tool that steals passwords saved in victim email.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

Name: Chat Messages
Description: The threat actors has targeted various collaboration tools like Slack, Teams, JIRA, Confluence, and others to hunt for exposed credentials to support privilege escalation and lateral movement.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has accessed files to gain valid credentials.

Name: Group Policy Preferences
Description: The threat actors has used a variety of publicly available tools like Gpppassword to gather credentials.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has used a variety of publicly available tools like the malware to gather credentials.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: The threat actors used Outlook Credential Dumper to harvest credentials stored in Windows registry.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: The threat actors has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.

Name: Private Keys
Description: During the attack, the threat actors obtained PKI keys, certificate files, and the private encryption key from an Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) container to decrypt corresponding SAML signing certificates.

Name: Private Keys
Description: During the attack, threat actors used the malware to dump certificates and private keys from the Windows certificate store.

Name: Credentials In Files
Description: Adversaries may search local file systems and remote file shares for files containing insecurely stored credentials. These can be files created by users to store their own credentials, shared credential stores for a group of individuals, configuration files containing passwords for a system or service, or source code/binary files containing embedded passwords.

Name: Credentials in Registry
Description: Adversaries may search the Registry on compromised systems for insecurely stored credentials. The Windows Registry stores configuration information that can be used by the system or other programs. Adversaries may query the Registry looking for credentials and passwords that have been stored for use by other programs or services. Sometimes these credentials are used for automatic logons.

Name: Bash History
Description: Adversaries may search the bash command history on compromised systems for insecurely stored credentials. Bash keeps track of the commands users type on the command-line with the "history" utility. Once a user logs out, the history is flushed to the user’s .bash_history file. For each user, this file resides at the same location: ~/.bash_history. Typically, this file keeps track of the user’s last 500 commands. Users often type usernames and passwords on the command-line as parameters to programs, which then get saved to this file when they log out. Adversaries can abuse this by looking through the file for potential credentials.

Name: Private Keys
Description: Adversaries may search for private key certificate files on compromised systems for insecurely stored credentials. Private cryptographic keys and certificates are used for authentication, encryption/decryption, and digital signatures. Common key and certificate file extensions include: .key, .pgp, .gpg, .ppk., .p12, .pem, .pfx, .cer, .p7b, .asc.

Name: Cloud Instance Metadata API
Description: Adversaries may attempt to access the Cloud Instance Metadata API to collect credentials and other sensitive data.

Name: Group Policy Preferences
Description: Adversaries may attempt to find unsecured credentials in Group Policy Preferences (GPP). GPP are tools that allow administrators to create domain policies with embedded credentials. These policies allow administrators to set local accounts.

Name: Container API
Description: Adversaries may gather credentials via APIs within a containers environment. APIs in these environments, such as the Docker API and Kubernetes APIs, allow a user to remotely manage their container resources and cluster components.

Name: Unused/Unsupported Cloud Regions
Description: Adversaries may create cloud instances in unused geographic service regions in order to evade detection. Access is usually obtained through compromising accounts used to manage cloud infrastructure.

Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material
Description: Adversaries may use alternate authentication material, such as password hashes, Kerberos tickets, and application access tokens, in order to move laterally within an environment and bypass normal system access controls.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: Some the malware samples have a module to use pass the ticket with Kerberos for authentication.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: The malware can also perform pass-the-ticket.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware has a number of modules that leverage pass the hash for lateral movement.

Name: Application Access Token
Description: The malware can use stolen service account tokens to perform its operations. It also enables adversaries to switch between valid service accounts.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware can perform pass the hash.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: The malware’s LSADUMP::DCSyncand KERBEROS::PTTmodules implement the three steps required to extract the krbtgt account hash and create/use Kerberos tickets.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware's SEKURLSA::Pthmodule can impersonate a user, with only a password hash, to execute arbitrary commands.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware has been observed loading several APIs associated with Pass the Hash.

Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material
Description: The malware can allow abuse of a compromised AD FS server's SAML token.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware can perform pass the hash attacks.

Name: Application Access Token
Description: The malware can use legitimate OAuth refresh tokens to authenticate with OneDrive.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware can pass the hash to authenticate via SMB.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The malware can perform pass the hash.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The threat actors has used pass the hash for authentication to remote access software used in C2.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The threat actors used dumped hashes to authenticate to other machines via pass the hash.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The threat actors has dumped password hashes for use in pass the hash authentication attacks.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: The threat actors has created forged Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) and Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets to maintain administrative access.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: The threat actors successfully gained remote access by using pass the ticket.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The threat actors has used pass the hash for lateral movement.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: The threat actors used Kerberos ticket attacks for lateral movement.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The threat actors has used pass the hash for lateral movement.

Name: Application Access Token
Description: The threat actors has used several malicious applications that abused OAuth access tokens to gain access to target email accounts, including Gmail and Yahoo Mail.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: The threat actors group is known to have used pass the hash.

Name: Web Session Cookie
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used stolen cookies to access cloud resources and a forged `duo-sid` cookie to bypass MFA set on an email account.

Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used forged SAML tokens that allowed the actors to impersonate users and bypass MFA, enabling the threat actors to access enterprise cloud applications and services.

Name: Application Access Token
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used compromised service principals to make changes to the Office 365 environment.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: During the attack, threat actors used pass-the-hash tools to obtain authenticated access to sensitive internal desktops and servers.

Name: Application Access Token
Description: Adversaries may use stolen application access tokens to bypass the typical authentication process and access restricted accounts, information, or services on remote systems. These tokens are typically stolen from users or services and used in lieu of login credentials.

Name: Pass the Hash
Description: Adversaries may "pass the hash" using stolen password hashes to move laterally within an environment, bypassing normal system access controls. Pass the hash (PtH) is a method of authenticating as a user without having access to the user's cleartext password. This method bypasses standard authentication steps that require a cleartext password, moving directly into the portion of the authentication that uses the password hash.

Name: Pass the Ticket
Description: Adversaries may "pass the ticket" using stolen Kerberos tickets to move laterally within an environment, bypassing normal system access controls. Pass the ticket (PtT) is a method of authenticating to a system using Kerberos tickets without having access to an account's password. Kerberos authentication can be used as the first step to lateral movement to a remote system.

Name: Web Session Cookie
Description: Adversaries can use stolen session cookies to authenticate to web applications and services. This technique bypasses some multi-factor authentication protocols since the session is already authenticated.

Name: User Execution
Description: An adversary may rely upon specific actions by a user in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to execute malicious code by, for example, opening a malicious document file or link. These user actions will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from forms of Phishing.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has relied on victims to open a malicious attachment delivered via email.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has relied on users opening a malicious email attachment for execution.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has relied on a victim to open a malicious attachment within an email for execution.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has been executed via Microsoft Word documents containing malicious macros.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has attempted to get users to launch malicious documents to deliver its payload.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware relies on a victim to click on a malicious document for initial execution.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has relied upon a victim to click on a malicious email attachment.

Name: Malicious File
Description: A Word document delivering the malware prompts the user to enable macro execution.

Name: Malicious Link
Description: The malware has been executed via malicious links embedded in e-mails spoofing the Ministries of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of Japan.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has been executed via compromised installation files for legitimate software including compression applications, security software, browsers, file recovery applications, and other tools and utilities.

Name: Malicious Link
Description: The malware has relied on victims to click on a malicious link send via phishing campaigns.

Name: Malicious File
Description: The malware has relied on users enabling malicious macros within Microsoft Excel and Word attachments.

Name: Malicious Link
Description: The malware has been executed through malicious links within spearphishing emails.

Name: Malicious Link

Name: Malicious Link
Description: An adversary may rely upon a user clicking a malicious link in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to click on a link that will lead to code execution. This user action will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from Spearphishing Link. Clicking on a link may also lead to other execution techniques such as exploitation of a browser or application vulnerability via Exploitation for Client Execution. Links may also lead users to download files that require execution via Malicious File.

Name: Malicious File
Description: An adversary may rely upon a user opening a malicious file in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to open a file that will lead to code execution. This user action will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from Spearphishing Attachment. Adversaries may use several types of files that require a user to execute them, including .doc, .pdf, .xls, .rtf, .scr, .exe, .lnk, .pif, and .cpl.

Name: Malicious Image
Description: Adversaries may rely on a user running a malicious image to facilitate execution. Amazon Web Services (AWS) Amazon Machine Images (AMIs), Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Images, and Azure Images as well as popular container runtimes such as Docker can be backdoored. Backdoored images may be uploaded to a public repository via Upload Malware, and users may then download and deploy an instance or container from the image without realizing the image is malicious, thus bypassing techniques that specifically achieve Initial Access. This can lead to the execution of malicious code, such as code that executes cryptocurrency mining, in the instance or container.

Name: Valid Accounts
Description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of existing accounts as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion. Compromised credentials may be used to bypass access controls placed on various resources on systems within the network and may even be used for persistent access to remote systems and externally available services, such as VPNs, Outlook Web Access and remote desktop. Compromised credentials may also grant an adversary increased privilege to specific systems or access to restricted areas of the network. Adversaries may choose not to use malware or tools in conjunction with the legitimate access those credentials provide to make it harder to detect their presence.

Name: Local Accounts
Description: The malware creates valid local users to provide access to the system.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Domain Accounts
Description: The malware attempts to access network resources with a domain account’s credentials.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Default Accounts
Description: The malware infected WinCC machines via a hardcoded database server password.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Domain Accounts
Description: If the malware cannot access shares using current privileges, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Valid Accounts
Description: Some the malware samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Domain Accounts
Description: The malware can use stolen domain admin accounts to move laterally within a victim domain.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Cloud Accounts
Description: The malware leverages valid cloud credentials to perform enumeration operations using the internal Azure AD Graph API.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Cloud Accounts
Description: The malware can use stolen service account tokens to perform its operations.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Local Accounts

tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Valid Accounts

tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Valid Accounts
Description: The malware can use supplied user credentials to execute processes and stop services.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Default Accounts

tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Local Accounts
Description: The malware can brute force a local admin password, then use it to facilitate lateral movement.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Valid Accounts

The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.
tactics: Defense Evasion, Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation

Name: Default Accounts
Description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of a default account as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion. Default accounts are those that are built-into an OS, such as the Guest or Administrator accounts on Windows systems. Default accounts also include default factory/provider set accounts on other types of systems, software, or devices, including the root user account in AWS and the default service account in Kubernetes.

Name: Domain Accounts
Description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of a domain account as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion. Domain accounts are those managed by Active Directory Domain Services where access and permissions are configured across systems and services that are part of that domain. Domain accounts can cover users, administrators, and services.

Name: Local Accounts
Description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of a local account as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion. Local accounts are those configured by an organization for use by users, remote support, services, or for administration on a single system or service.

Name: Cloud Accounts
Description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of a cloud account as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion. Cloud accounts are those created and configured by an organization for use by users, remote support, services, or for administration of resources within a cloud service provider or SaaS application. In some cases, cloud accounts may be federated with traditional identity management system, such as Window Active Directory.

Name: Video Capture
Description: An adversary can leverage a computer's peripheral devices (e.g., integrated cameras or webcams) or applications (e.g., video call services) to capture video recordings for the purpose of gathering information. Images may also be captured from devices or applications, potentially in specified intervals, in lieu of video files.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has some basic anti-sandbox detection that tries to detect Virtual PC, Sandboxie, and VMware.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has delayed execution for five to six minutes during its persistence establishment process.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can parse the output of the native `system_profiler` tool to determine if the machine is running with 4 cores.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: Using the machine's local time, the malware waits 43200 seconds (12 hours) from the initial creation timestamp of a specific file, .report. After the elapsed time, the malware executes additional modules.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can pause for 20 seconds to bypass antivirus solutions.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can stop its execution when it recognizes the presence of certain monitoring tools.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware checked if UCOMIEnumConnections and IActiveScriptParseProcedure32 Registry keys were detected as part of its anti-analysis technique.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has used a 30 minute delay after execution to evade sandbox monitoring tools.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can detect commonly used and generic virtualization platforms based primarily on drivers and file paths.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has used printfand file I/O loops to delay process execution as part of API hammering.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to sleep for at least nine minutes to evade sandbox-based analysis systems.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware invokes timecall to check the system's time, executes a sleepcommand, invokes a second timecall, and then compares the time difference between the two timecalls and the amount of time the system slept to identify the sandbox.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can modify its sleep time responses from the default of 20-22 seconds.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has used several anti-emulation techniques to prevent automated analysis by emulators or sandboxes.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has contained a hardcoded list of IP addresses to block that belong to sandboxes and analysis platforms.

Name: User Activity Based Checks
Description: The malware has used a splash screen to check whether an user actively clicks on the screen before running malicious code.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to put itself to "sleep" for a specified time.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check for the presence of the Registry key HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\\Applications\\VMwareHostOpen.exebefore proceeding to its main functionality.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware scans processes to perform anti-VM checks.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can stop execution if the screen width of the targeted machine is not over 600 pixels.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has used the command `timeout 20` to pause the execution of its initial loader.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has run several virtual machine and sandbox checks, including checking if `Sbiedll.dll` is present in a list of loaded modules, comparing the machine name to `HAL9TH` and the user name to `JohnDoe`, and checking the BIOS version for known virtual machine identifiers.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can enter a sleep stage for 30 minutes to evade detection.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has the ability to determine if its runtime environment is virtualized.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware remained dormant after initial access for a period of up to two weeks.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware checked the domain name of the compromised host to verify it was running in a real environment.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware uses WMI to check BIOS version for VBOX, bochs, qemu, virtualbox, and vm to check for evidence that the script might be executing within an analysis environment.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware searches for Sandboxie and VMware on the system.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: After initial installation, the malware runs a computation to delay execution.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware can detect if it is running within a sandbox or other virtualized analysis environment.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check for VMware-related files and DLLs related to sandboxes.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware dropper can delay dropping the payload to evade detection.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check the compromised host for the presence of multiple executables associated with analysis tools and halt execution if any are found.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has a module that checks a number of indicators on the system to determine if its running on a virtual machine.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to use anti-detection functions to identify sandbox environments.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has delayed execution using a built-in function to avoid detection and analysis.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware checked the size of the hard drive to determine if it was being run in a sandbox environment. In the event of sandbox detection, it would delete itself by overwriting the malware scripts with the contents of "License.txt" and exiting.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware checks if VMware tools is running in the background by searching for any process named "vmtoolsd".

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to "sleep" for a specified time to evade detection.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check the compromised host for processes associated with VMware or VirtualBox environments.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperatureto check the temperature to see if it’s running in a virtual environment.

Name: User Activity Based Checks
Description: The malware loader only executes the payload after the left mouse button has been pressed at least three times, in order to avoid being executed within virtualized or emulated environments.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware's loader can detect presence of an emulator by using two calls to GetTickCount API, and checking whether the time has been accelerated.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware's loader can check the amount of physical memory and terminates itself if the host has less than 1.5 Gigabytes of physical memory in total.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can halt execution if it identifies processes belonging to virtual machine software or analysis tools.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has variants that check a number of system parameters to see if it is being run on real hardware or in a virtual machine environment, such as sysctl hw.model.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has checked if Vmware or VirtualBox VM is running on a compromised host.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has embedded a "vmdetect.exe" executable to identify virtual machines at the beginning of execution.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has checked the number of CPUs in the system to avoid being run in a sandbox or emulator.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check for specific usernames, computer names, device drivers, DLL's, and virtual devices associated with sandboxed environments and can enter an infinite loop and stop itself if any are detected.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has performed a time-based anti-debug check before downloading its third stage.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can wait 30 seconds before executing additional code if security software is detected.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware can sleep for a time interval between C2 communication attempts.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check for artifacts of VirtualBox, Virtual PC and VMware environment, and terminate itself if they are detected.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to receive a command parameter to sleep prior to carrying out destructive actions on a targeted host.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has used a macro to check that an ActiveDocument shape object in the lure message is present. If this object is not found, the macro will exit without downloading additional payloads.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to perform anti-debugging based on time checks, API calls, and CPUID.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has the ability to perform anti-VM and anti-sandbox checks using string hashing, the API call EnumWindows, and checking for Qemu guest agent.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can sleep for 195 - 205 seconds after payload execution and before deleting its task.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware uses WMI to check the BIOS and manufacturer information for strings like "VMWare", "Virtual", and "XEN" and another WMI request to get the current temperature of the hardware to determine if it's a virtual machine environment.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can detect VMWare via its I/O port and Virtual PC via the vpcextinstruction.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware's installer has delayed installation of the malware for two hours after it reaches a victim system.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has set an execution trigger date and time, stored as an ASCII Unix/Epoch time value.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware will check if it is being run in a virtualized environment by comparing the collected MAC address to c8:27:cc:c2:37:5a.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware can use junk code to generate random activity to obscure malware behavior.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware obtains the hardware device list and checks if the MD5 of the vendor ID is equal to a predefined list in order to check for sandbox/virtualized environments.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can run anti-sandbox checks using the Microsoft Excel 4.0 function GET.WORKSPACEto determine the OS version, if there is a mouse present, and if the host is capable of playing sounds.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can turn itself on or off at random intervals.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has used time measurements from 3 different APIs before and after performing sleep operations to check and abort if the malware is running in a sandbox.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware's dropper has checked the number of processes and the length and strings of its own file name to identify if the malware is in a sandbox environment.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has used multiple anti-analysis and anti-sandbox techniques to prevent automated analysis by sandboxes.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can perform a  long sleep (greater than or equal to 3 minutes) to evade detection.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can detect sandbox analysis environments by inspecting the process list and Registry.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware ran multiple system checks, looking for processor and register characteristics, to evade emulation and analysis.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can implement the `kernel32.dll` Sleep function to delay execution for up to 300 seconds before implementing persistence or processing an addon package.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can search a compromised system's running processes and services to detect Hyper-V, QEMU, Virtual PC, Virtual Box, and VMware, as well as Sandboxie.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description:
The malware can use the `GetTickCount` and `GetSystemTimeAsFileTime` API calls to measure function timing. the malware can also remotely shut down into sleep mode under specific conditions to evade 
detection.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can determine when it has been installed on a host for at least 15 days before downloading the final payload.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: Some versions of the malware will check to ensure it is not being executed inside a virtual machine or a known malware analysis sandbox environment. If it detects that it is, it will exit.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has used the sleepcommand to avoid sandbox detection.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can wait 30 minutes before initiating contact with C2.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has removed various hooks before installing the trojan or bootkit to evade sandbox analysis or other analysis software.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can search loaded modules, PEB structure, file paths, Registry keys, and memory to determine if it is being debugged or running in a virtual environment.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware  includes runtime checks to identify an analysis environment and prevent execution on it.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to perform anti-virtualization checks.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has the ability to set a hardcoded and randomized sleep interval.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware has the ability to search for designated file paths and Registry keys that indicate a virtualized environment from multiple products.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can call `NtDelayExecution` to pause execution.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware can make a random number of calls to the `kernel32.beep` function to hinder log analysis.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check system flags and libraries, process timing, and API's to detect code emulation or sandboxing.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware can check to determine if the compromised system is running on VMware.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has checked if the malware is running in a virtual environment with the anti-debug function GetTickCount() to compare the timing.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can check for analysis environments and signs of debugging using the Windows API kernel32!GetTickCountKernel32call.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware can attempt to overload sandbox analysis by sending 1550 calls to printf.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware can use a timer to delay execution of core functionality.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware attempts to detect if it is being run in a Virtual Machine (VM) using a WMI query for disk drive name, BIOS, and motherboard information.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check to see if the infected machine has VM tools running.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has delayed communication to the actor-controlled IP address by 5 minutes.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can detect whether it is executed in some virtualized or emulated environment by searching for specific artifacts, such as communication with I/O ports and using VM-specific instructions.

Name: System Checks
Description: The malware can check for Windows product ID's used by sandboxes and usernames and disk serial numbers associated with analyst environments.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: The malware has waited a specified time before downloading a second stage payload.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The malware has he ability to perform anti-sandboxing and anti-virtualization checks.

Name: System Checks
Description: The threat actors has used macros to verify if a mouse is connected to a compromised machine.

Name: User Activity Based Checks
Description: The threat actors used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.

Name: System Checks
Description: The threat actors has used a component called TerraLoader to check certain hardware and file information to detect sandboxed environments.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: The threat actors malware has employed just-in-time decryption of strings to evade sandbox detection.

Name: User Activity Based Checks
Description: The threat actors has used malware that repeatedly checks the mouse cursor position to determine if a real user is on the system.

Name: System Checks
Description: The threat actors malware has used a series of checks to determine if it's being analyzed; checks include the length of executable names, if a filename ends with .Md5.exe, and if the program is executed from the root of the C:\ drive, as well as checks for sandbox-related libraries.

Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used droppers that would run anti-analysis checks before executing malware on a compromised host.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used tools that collected `GetTickCount` and `GetSystemTimeAsFileTime` data to detect sandbox or VMware services.

Name: System Checks
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used tools that conducted a variety of system checks to detect sandboxes or VMware services.

Name: System Checks
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used a script that ran WMI queries to check if a VM or sandbox was running, including VMWare and Virtualbox. The script would also call WMI to determine the number of cores allocated to the system; if less than two the script would stop execution.

Name: System Checks
Description: Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.

Name: User Activity Based Checks
Description: Adversaries may employ various user activity checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.

Name: Time Based Evasion
Description: Adversaries may employ various time-based methods to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include enumerating time-based properties, such as uptime or the system clock, as well as the use of timers or other triggers to avoid a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox, specifically those that are automated or only operate for a limited amount of time.

Name: Weaken Encryption
Description: Adversaries may compromise a network device’s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications.

Name: Reduce Key Space
Description: Adversaries may reduce the level of effort required to decrypt data transmitted over the network by reducing the cipher strength of encrypted communications.

Name: Disable Crypto Hardware
Description: Adversaries disable a network device’s dedicated hardware encryption, which may enable them to leverage weaknesses in software encryption in order to reduce the effort involved in collecting, manipulating, and exfiltrating transmitted data.

Name: Web Service
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for relaying data to/from a compromised system. Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.

Name: Dead Drop Resolver
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service to host information that points to additional command and control (C2) infrastructure. Adversaries may post content, known as a dead drop resolver, on Web services with embedded (and often obfuscated/encoded) domains or IP addresses. Once infected, victims will reach out to and be redirected by these resolvers.

Name: Bidirectional Communication
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet.

Name: One-Way Communication
Description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to a compromised system without receiving return output over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems may opt to send the output from those commands back over a different C2 channel, including to another distinct Web service. Alternatively, compromised systems may return no output at all in cases where adversaries want to send instructions to systems and do not want a response.

Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Description: Adversaries may abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute malicious commands and payloads. WMI is an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components. The WMI service enables both local and remote access, though the latter is facilitated by Remote Services such as Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) and Windows Remote Management (WinRM). Remote WMI over DCOM operates using port 135, whereas WMI over WinRM operates over port 5985 when using HTTP and 5986 for HTTPS.

Name: XSL Script Processing
Description: Adversaries may bypass application control and obscure execution of code by embedding scripts inside XSL files. Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) files are commonly used to describe the processing and rendering of data within XML files. To support complex operations, the XSL standard includes support for embedded scripting in various languages.

Name: XSL Script Processing
Description: The malware executes embedded JScript or VBScript in an XSL stylesheet located on a remote domain.

Name: XSL Script Processing
Description: The threat actors used an XSL file to run VBScript code.

Name: XSL Script Processing
Description: The threat actors used msxsl.exe to bypass AppLocker and to invoke Jscript code from an XSL file.

Name: XSL Script Processing
Description: During the attack, the threat actors used a remote XSL script to download a Base64-encoded DLL custom downloader.
